cookies-policy.title: Cookies Policy
cookies-policy.content:
Esta POLÍTICA DE COOKIES forma parte de la POLÍTICA DE PRIVACIDAD de la Web de STOP BILBAO SLU con dirección postal en C/ Rodriguez Arias 6, dpto 607 – 48008 Bilbao (en adelante STOP).

En concreto, la web responsabilidad de STOP es: www.stop.es y www.spaincollection.com La navegación por la Web y la utilización de cualquiera de sus servicios implican la aceptación del uso que hacemos de las cookies y de esta Política.

¿Qué es una Cookie?

Las cookies son pequeños ficheros enviados al navegador que utiliza su equipo y sirven para intentar reconocer al usuario, para almacenar, recuperar y/o actualizar datos que nos permiten facilitarle el uso y navegación a través de la página Web, garantizar el acceso a determinadas funcionalidades y, adicionalmente, nos ayudan a mejorar la calidad de la página de acuerdo con los hábitos y estilos de navegación de cada usuario.

Siempre que se pueda relacionar a un determinado equipo y un navegador con un usuario se puede ver afectada su privacidad y, por eso, le informamos que puede desactivar las cookies mediante la configuración de su navegador.

¿Cómo desactivar las Cookies?

El usuario que no desee recibir o mantener cookies en su equipo, o quiera ser informado de su fijación, puede configurar sus preferencias desde su navegador. En caso de desactivar las cookies, algunas funcionalidades de la Web podrían no responder correctamente. Puede encontrar la información sobre cómo desinstalar las cookies, en función del navegador que utilice, en las direcciones siguientes:

  • Si utiliza Firefox: http://support.mozilla.org/es/kb/habilitar-y-deshabilitar-cookies-que-lossitios-we
  • Si utiliza Chrome: https://support.google.com/chrome/answer/95647?hl=se
  • Si utiliza Internet Explorer: http://support.microsoft.com/kb/196955
  • Si utiliza Safari: http://support.apple.com/kb/ht1677?viewlocale=es_es
  • Si utiliza Opera: http://help.opera.com/windows/11.50/es-es/cookies.html

También puede cambiar la configuración de las cookies haciendo clic en el siguiente enlace:

Cookie settings

 

Estas fuentes se facilitan a título informativo, sin ningún compromiso sobre su actualización por parte de STOP y no son las únicas vías para obtener la información sobre su navegador.

Para obtener información actualizada, diríjase a la página Web oficial del navegador.

Tipología de Cookies utilizadas

Con el objetivo de garantizar su privacidad y para que usted tenga plena capacidad de decisión en relación con el uso de las cookies, le informamos que navegando por la Web de

STOP se pueden utilizar los siguientes tipos:

  • Cookies técnicas: son aquellas que permiten al usuario la navegación a través de la página Web o aplicación y la utilización de las diferentes opciones o servicios que en ella existen. Por ejemplo, identificar la sesión, balanceo de carga para una sesión, realizar la solicitud de inscripción o participación en un acontecimiento, utilizar elementos de seguridad durante la navegación y almacenar contenidos para la difusión de vídeos o sonido.
  • Cookies de personalización: son aquellas que permiten al usuario acceder al servicio con algunas características de carácter general predefinidas en su terminal o que el mismo usuario define. Por ejemplo, el idioma, cantidad de elementos por página, filtros o criterios de ordenación u opciones de menú visitadas.
  • Cookies analíticas o de análisis estadístico: estas cookies están establecidas normalmente por Google Analytics y se utilizan para analizar la navegación que se realiza por la página Web. Estas informaciones se utilizan para hacer análisis estadísticos que nos ayudan a mejorar nuestra página Web. Estas cookies recopilan información de manera anónima sobre nuestros visitantes, incluyendo el número de visitantes a nuestra página Web, identificando las Webs que los han redirigido hasta la nuestra, las páginas que han visitado dentro de nuestra Web, el tiempo dedicado en cada página, los acontecimientos que han sido utilizados, qué páginas se visitan más…

(Puede obtener más información en: http://www.google.com/policies/technologies/types/)

  • Cookies de sesión: son aquellas que expiran cuando el usuario cierra el navegador. Es decir, son ficheros que se asignan al dispositivo desde el cual se navega sólo durante su visita en nuestra Web y desaparecen automáticamente cuando se cierra el navegador.
  • Cookies permanentes: son las que expiran sólo cuando cumplen la finalidad para la cual sirven y, por lo tanto, no finalizan necesariamente de forma automática al cerrar la sesión.
  • Cookies de terceros: son aquellas que se envían a la terminal del usuario desde un equipo o dominio que no es gestionado por STOP , sino por otra entidad que trata los datos obtenidos a través de las cookies. Por ejemplo: desde alguna red social.
  • Cookies sociales: son necesarias en las redes sociales para controlar la interacción con el lugar Web.

Así mismo, es posible que en alguna visita a nuestra página Web o al abrir algún correo electrónico en que se publique algún anuncio o alguna promoción sobre nuestros productos o servicios, se instale en su navegador alguna cookie que nos sirva para mostrar posteriormente publicidad relacionada con la búsqueda que haya realizado o desarrollar un control de nuestros anuncios. Por ejemplo: conocer el número a veces que son vistos, dónde aparecen, a qué hora se ven, etc.

Todas estas cookies nos ayudan a mejorar el servicio que le ofrecemos. De este modo podemos facilitar que nuestros usuarios encuentren la información que desean.

La versión en castellano de este documento es la única válida con efectos legales. Cualquier otra versión es una mera traducción sin más efectos que los de facilitar su comprensión.

privacy-policy.title: Privacy Policy
privacy-policy.content:
El presente documento constituye la política de privacidad de la web de Spain Collection, marca de STOP Bilbao SLU.

¿Quién es el responsable del tratamiento de sus datos?

El responsable del tratamiento de sus datos es STOP BILBAO SLU con dirección postal en C/ Rodriguez Arias 6, dpto 607 – 48008 Bilbao (en adelante STOP). Para cualquier cuestión en materia de protección de datos, puede ponerse en contacto con STOP a través de correo

postal y también a través del siguiente correo electrónico travel@spaincollection.com.

¿Qué datos personales necesitamos, de dónde proceden y con qué finalidad los tratamos?

STOP sólo recaba datos de identificación y de envío postal o electrónico, facilitados por el propio interesado, con la finalidad de facilitarle la información que pueda haber solicitado específicamente u otra información que pueda ser de su interés, relativa a los servicios de

Spain Collection. Normalmente, la información se facilita por medios electrónicos, como por ejemplo un e-mail.

¿Qué hace legítimo el tratamiento de sus datos?

Solamente su consentimiento expreso al envío de esta información puede hacer legítimo el tratamiento de sus datos, de tal modo que usted puede revocar este consentimiento en cualquier momento, con sólo comunicarlo.

Usted expresa su consentimiento al envío de esta información mediante un acto afirmativo claro, libre, específico e informado, al cumplimentar el formulario y enviarlo a STOP .

Es posible que, en algunos casos, sus datos deban ser facilitados a proveedores de correos o de otro tipo de países distintos de los que forman el Espacio Económico Europeo para atender su petición, por lo que su consentimiento expreso debe incluir este hecho de ser necesario.

¿Por cuánto tiempo conservaremos sus datos?

Conservaremos sus daros mientras nuestra información le resulte útil. Los datos tratados para el envío de comunicaciones comerciales serán conservados hasta que usted revoque el consentimiento al envío de información por medios electrónicos o ejercite su derecho de supresión.

¿A qué destinatarios se comunicarán sus datos?

Toda la información que nos facilite será tratada de forma confidencial y dando estricto cumplimiento a las obligaciones de seguridad necesarias para impedir el acceso por terceros no autorizados. Sus datos personales no serán comunicados a terceros salvo a aquellos proveedores, como Correos, que sean necesarios para que la información llegue a su destino, incluso si son de países diferentes a los del Espacio Económico Europeo.

¿Cuáles son sus derechos?

Aparte de poder revocar su consentimiento al envío de información, usted tiene derecho a saber qué datos tenemos de usted y a conocer de dónde los hemos obtenido, además de la información al respecto que ya le facilitamos en esta Política de Privacidad.

Además, tiene derecho a solicitar que sus datos sean rectificados de ser inexactos o desactualizados; a solicitar su supresión, cuando usted quiera y, especialmente, cuando ya no sean necesarios para los fines que fueron recogidos; en determinadas circunstancias también podrá solicitar la limitación del tratamiento de sus datos, en cuyo caso los conservaremos para el ejercicio o defensa de reclamaciones; también puede solicitar su portabilidad a otra entidad cuando sea técnicamente posible y a ejercitar el derecho de oposición.

Para ello, tan sólo es preciso que se dirija mediante un escrito firmado a C/ Rodriguez Arias 6, dpto 607 – 48008 Bilbao o a travel@spaincollection.com, aportando fotocopia de su DNI o de otro documento oficial de identificación, válido, e indicando el derecho que desea ejercitar.

Además, también puede presentar una reclamación ante una autoridad de control, como puede ser la Agencia Española de Protección de datos.

features.title: Mission
features.text: Deliver outstanding travel experiences in Spain and Portugal that are authentic, supportive of local businesses and a source of inspiration to our own staff.

features.title: Vision
features.text: To become the global ambassador for Spain and Portugal for discerning travelers who journey to connect and engage with cultures, traditions, and destinations in a sustainable, inclusive and mindful way with a touch of luxury.

features.title: Values
features.text:
As a company we believe in a life-affirming, sense of purpose. We look for engagement, innovation, diversity and inclusion. We are mindful of others and sensitive to the environment. Communication is real, open and transparent, and our working relationships are mutually beneficial and respectful.

It is not what we do but the way we do it

fields.featured_text:
One of the things I learned about being leader is that some people are only motivated by money, or they are only motivated by power or some kind of incentive. But people also get inspired by stories. Here I share just a few thoughts from my team about Spain & Portugal Collection…

 

We really appreciate your considering us as partners!

list.list_intro: Born and raised in a little town in Extremadura, western Spain, I come from a very large family.  Dozens of first cousins and tons of friends meant that I spent most of my childhood playing out in the street.  Without doubt this instilled in me a deep love for the outdoors and the countryside.
list.list_text:
After one year at law school I went on to study tourism at the Official School of Tourism in Madrid. Passionate about Spain, its history and culture, I started showing this exciting country first to my family and friends, and then professionally to others as I opened my first travel agency in the university city of Salamanca.

 

I lived in the United States for several years before moving back home to Spain to work as a guide specializing in religious heritage. Having escorted hundreds of travelers from overseas around the Iberian Peninsula, I call El Camino de Santiago my “path of life” as it is, by far, my favorite itinerary. I have done the classic French Camino, the Primitive Route and the less traveled Portuguese Camino covering several thousand miles by foot overall! I realized I had become part of El Camino, when a friend working at a local inn, kept saving the last piece of cake for me and started calling it “the JC doughnut” ☺

 

Passionate about life, food and motorcycles I have indulged myself at some of the world’s most famous Michelin-star restaurants in Spain and Portugal, including the iconic El Bulli. If you don’t find me reaching the end of the earth on foot in Finisterre, I may very well be getting lost in Ushuaia on a BMW motorbike…

list.list_intro: I was born in Bilbao and have lived here most of my life. Most of my professional career has been dedicated to the world of corporate events and the incentive travel sector, at Stop, the mother company of Spain Collection.
list.list_text:
Euskadi is a unique destination, because despite being small, its cities exude class and very distinct style. Each of its defining characteristics are striking especially with regards to gastronomy, but also with regards to its history, its language, its traditions and its way of understanding life and work.

 

I lived in the Canaries for 7 years.  I know the islands really well, and appreciate that this region is vastly different to the rest of Spain. There are no two extremes more polar opposite in this country than the Basque Country and the Canary Islands, not only with regards to distance but also in terms of culture and history. In my opinion, Spain is probably the country where more ‘universes’ coexist than anywhere else in the world.

list.list_intro: I come from a little fishing town in the Basque Country, the northern part of Spain, where I happily grew in a very familiar environment. I studied Computer Science Engineering and a Master on Online Marketing, which took me to start my profesional career in different marketing agencies. However in my early twenties I did my first overseas trip to Latin America and the travel bug bit me so bad I had to make a major switch in my life: I changed the office for the road and since then I became a passionate traveler.
list.list_text:
I worked as a tour leader in Central America and Mexico for five years where I led close to a thousand worldwide travelers. Throughout that remarkable time I had the chance to experience and master such a diverse and ancestral culture, explore the most remote places of the Mayan civilization, learn to cook in a shared kitchen with local families, understand the power of the community feeling, the environment and the respect for sustainability… I’m very proud to say that I love my job and I feel grateful to be able to share my passion and experience of traveling with everyone.

 

This enriching journey has already become a lifestyle that has taken me back to my roots in Spain, where I have found my little piece of paradise and I’m determined with the unstoppable desire of sharing my love for this unique and fascinating country and everything it has to offer.

483.title: Easter in Spain or where passion meets art and tradition
483.excerpt: La Semana Santa, Easter week, is undoubtedly the most special and spectacular religious event of the year for the Spanish.

flexible.wysiwyg:
There is no other country in the world where religious fervor and local ancestral traditions intertwine so deeply into the locals’ daily lives. Right after Ash Wednesday the whole country fills with the scent of candles and incense. Almost every town and village in the country has a local Semana Santa celebration of their own.

 

Andalusia is probably the best example of where this religious sentiment permeates to the deepest level in its population. Most families will have at least one member in a “cofradía” or brotherhood. These “cofradías” are local custodians of the rites and traditions during Easter Week. Every brotherhood has a dedicated devotion to which they profess. This has led to a very unique religious art form known as “imagineria”. Some of these iconic pieces of art, called “pasos”, are centuries old and are taken out on processions, and some of them can weigh over a ton. They are carried through the streets by dozens of “costaleros” who carry the structure on their shoulders.
flexible.excerpt: La Semana Santa, Easter week, is undoubtedly the most special and spectacular religious event of the year for the Spanish.

flexible.title: Most families will have at least one member in a “cofradía” or brotherhood. These ‘cofradías’ are local custodians of the rites and traditions during Easter Week.

flexible.wysiwyg:
Seville and Malaga are two cities where you can definitely get caught up in the fervor and passion at this unique time of the year. As the heavily ornate “pasos” parade through the streets flanked by marching bands, prepare to be moved by the haunting songs or “saetas” the devoted locals sing with their broken voices from their balconies.

 

Unlike the colorful and more vivid celebrations of Andalusia, Semana Santa is lived in a more sober and modest way in central Spain, especially in the region of Castille. The master sculptors of Castile worked in a different style, and their “pasos” in cities like Zamora or Valladolid portray an image of the passion of Christ in a much more sober and solemn manner. Castilian processions are, therefore, quieter, even silent at times yet full of profound religious sentiment. That sentiment can become excessive in some cities and villages of Spain, and are for the not faint-hearted. You might be shocked by the raw manifestations of the “Empalaos” in the region of Extremadura where the penitents are chained and barefoot, or the “Picaos” in La Rioja, where they walk the streets self-flagellating.
flexible.excerpt: One way or another, Semana Santa in Spain is definitely a unique experience, so save the date for next spring and head over to be engulfed in an array of emotions you will never forget.

2355.title: Hidden Gems of Andalucía: Antequera, it’s a kind of magic
2355.excerpt: Antequera is a beautiful town in the Malaga area, far from the hustle and bustle of the beaches of the Costa del Sol. It’s a place where history, culture and gastronomy are the protagonists.

flexible.wysiwyg:
ANTEQUERA, A “MOLLETE” FILLED WITH HISTORY.

Easily accessible sitting right in the center of Andalusia has meant that for thousands of years there have been important settlements here, all of which have left an invaluable heritage behind.

This diary entry, about visiting Antequera, is that of a 12-year-old girl – my daughter Lilián. We all have a child inside, so let’s see what was recorded in her memory, the sensations and experiences that will stay with her forever.

They say that the sense of smell is the human being’s strongest sense and that smells spark memories of emotions and experiences. Hence the powerful spell that perfumes have exerted on us since the beginning of time. Nowadays we call this “neuromarketing”. Marcel Proust’s evocative “magdalena” is, in this case, a freshly baked, golden bread roll, crunchy on the outside, and soft and cotton-like on the inside, dripping with extra virgin oil and smeared with passion-red tomato. This is the famous “MOLLETE” of Antequera”, a delicious type of bread and small gastronomic jewel. It has a very thin crust and a very spongy, very “springy”, soft interior, hence its name.

Antequera also tastes like “PORRA”, a kind of cold and thick soup made with tomatoes, very similar to salmorejo and whose origins dates back to the Roman period.

I asked my daughter what she liked best about the trip. After giving it some thought she said, “Mommy, the “PORRA” and the “MOLLETES”, the trip to El Torcal and being able to enter the Dolmens, but the best part was the food”.

I was not disappointed. Antequera also tastes of history, it’s an ancient land ravaged by erosion. It is without a doubt a paradise for a child to discover more of the world and for an adult who flees from it seeking peace and magic. Absolute magic.
flexible.excerpt: Antequera is a beautiful town in the Malaga area, far from the hustle and bustle of the beaches of the Costa del Sol. It’s a place where history, culture and gastronomy are the protagonists.

flexible.title: What image will stay in my mind’s eye? What will we see when we close our eyes and think of this incredible place? For sure the Dolmens, the Lover’s Rock and the impressive landscape of El Torcal.

flexible.wysiwyg:
My eyes are closed as I write these lines. I can feel the humidity of the stone and I relive the emotion my daughter and I felt when we entered the interior of the dolmens, which are part of one of the most important megalithic complexes in Europe. It is an amazing place, where you can feel the power of nature.

For the inhabitants of this area some 6,500 years ago this was a magical place and it still is. The dolmens of Menga, Viera, and the Tholos of El Romeral (circular funeral construction), face two natural landmarks: the Peña de los Enamorados (a hill in the shape of a human face) and El Torcal de Antequera. This is one of the first known examples of the integration of architecture and natural landscape in European prehistory.

This area demonstrates the ancestral union of man with nature. For this reason, on 15 July 2016, UNESCO declared the megalithic complex and the two natural monuments as World Heritage Sites. The visual impact for anyone open and receptive to this type of thing is huge. For two girls like us, one 12 and the other 49 years old, our jaws literally dropped in awe.

That’s why the next day Lilián and I, with walking shoes on and backpacks ready, spent the day in El Torcal, in an attempt to understand the relationship between the monuments.

 

The most important karst landscape in Europe.

El Torcal de Antequera is breath-taking, it makes you feel small and insignificant.  It’s like entering an unreal fairy world. The information center explains how it was formed, which to summarise, was due to wind and water erosion on the limestone rocks during the Jurassic period, between 250 and 150 million years ago. It is a unique place, as are the flora and fauna, so it is a must for lovers of nature in its purest form, and for lovers of silence, the wind and endless walks. It is like a petrified city, frozen in time. It looks like one of Gaudi’s masterpieces, a combination of the “Sagrada Familia” and “La Pedrera”, but yet it was Mother Nature who carved a spectacular collection of passageways and rock formations that make us feel like we’re on a different planet. Who knows if Gaudí walked here once?

On the last day of our little adventure, we decided to lose ourselves in the small streets of Antequera, and visit some of its museums, churches and convents – home to examples of baroque and renaissance art that are unparalleled. A visit of the town’s Alcazaba takes us back to the time of Muslim rule.

Antequera is like a box of chocolates, it may be small, but it has something for everyone. It is impossible to do it justice, you just have to come and see for yourself. Come and make wonderful memories, like those of my daughter.

And then come back again “À la recherche du temps perdu”.

El Camino de Santiago, making sense of life

2371.title: El Camino de Santiago, making sense of life
2371.excerpt: Our lives are based, a lot of the time, on endless questions, or to put it another way, on finding answers to our many questions about life

flexible.wysiwyg:
For me, El Camino de Santiago is simply the one experience that makes sense of them all. A journey that started as a religious pilgrimage back in the 9th century, has today become one of the most interesting cultural and spiritual experiences in Europe. The fact that this is mainly an adventure on foot, is a great leveler. Millions of people, of all shapes and sizes, have walked ‘the way’ regardless of their walk of life in the real world.

 

Once you have figured out the ‘what’ and ‘why’, you just need to work out the ‘when’ and ‘how’. As for the first one, do not ask me because the dust on my hiking boots never settles – I am ready to head back out on El Camino on any given day, sunshine or snow. Regarding the latter, of the many different routes, pick the one that catches your attention the most and just start with a short stretch of the walk. Most ‘peregrinos’ choose to do the last 100 kilometers, in order to obtain the pilgrims’ ‘certificate of completion’, known as the ‘Compostela’.
flexible.excerpt: Our lives are based, a lot of the time, on endless questions, or to put it another way, on finding answers to our many questions about life

flexible.title: The fact that this is mainly an adventure on foot, is a great leveler. Millions of people, of all shapes and sizes, have walked 'the way' regardless of their walk of life in the real world.

flexible.wysiwyg:
Should you decide to walk the so-called ‘French route’, the most popular route by far since the 13th century, the Galician village of Sarria will make the perfect start point for you. It is located approximately 110 kms (70 miles) from Santiago de Compostela and from here you will get the right amount of typical Galician mountain-like landscape on your way to Santiago. In terms of difficulty, it is an easy to moderate portion of El Camino and the stages can be broken down to average daily walks of about 20-25 kms (12-13 miles). The scenery along the way is fabulous and very rural for the most part. A chain of scattered aldeas (hamlets) and parroquias (parishes) populated with the typical horreos (Galician granaries) will welcome you as you follow the ubiquitous yellow arrows that were made so popular by father Valiña, a Galician priest who brought El Camino up to date in the 80s and turned it into the world famous walk that it is today.

 

For the first couple days, the natural landscape goes from farming land to stunning forests full of native oak and chestnut trees and then, as you get closer to Santiago you find the more abundant yet imported eucalyptus woods providing you some shelter either from rain or heat. As the scenery changes along the Camino, so does the food. Caldo Gallego (Galician soup), pulpo a feira (octopus with olive oil and paprika) or Galician empanada (this is so particular to this region that it doesn’t have a translation ☺ ) will become your daily local treats, just don’t forget to congratulate yourself and celebrate the end of every completed stage with a shot of local orujo, the traditional ‘fire water’!

 

El Camino is a sharing experience, but by the same token it is also a very personal and inner journey, so don’t let anyone tell you how you should walk, understand or live El Camino, as it will mean something different for everyone. At Spain Collection we are certain that once you try this small initial bite of ‘the Way’, it will stay with you forever and you will always be as one with El Camino… Ultreia!
flexible.excerpt: Should you decide to walk the so called “French route”, the most popular route by far since the 13th century, the Galician village of Sarria will make the perfect start for you.

2383.title: Ecotourism in Spain: Northern Catalonia
2383.excerpt: An outstanding combination of nature, history and gastronomy

flexible.wysiwyg:
Girona is a historical and archaeological jewel and was one of the most important economic hubs in Spain which meant that for many centuries it was home to various civilizations. The Romans were the first to settle in the 2nd century. Later it became a melting pot for different cultures – Christians, Muslims and Jews.

Girona is a perfect place to start an itinerary through northern Catalonia. It’s worth enjoying a couple of days in this wonderful city where you can get lost in its narrow streets and visit local shops like the historic Geli bookstore which dates back to 1879. Many might recognise the city as it was one of the locations chosen as a setting for Game of Thrones.

From Girona we continue to climb north up through medieval villages like Besalú or Castellfollit de la Roca where the cliff-top houses take you back to another era.  Eventually we will arrive at La Garrotxa, where the Volcanic Zone Natural Park is located. This is one of the most important volcanic landscapes in Europe, declared a Natural Site of National Interest in 1982. The natural beauty is something to behold. Garrotxa is also known for its “volcanic” cuisine plus there’s the handmade cheese and ratafia liquor made with nuts and brandy to try!
flexible.excerpt: From Barcelona airport it takes about an hour and a half to reach the city of Girona, the second most important city in the region. A great place to spend a few days before continuing on through the north of Catalonia.

flexible.title: A wild Mediterranean paradise with its small white Mediterranean villages and beaches with crystal clear waters

flexible.wysiwyg:
From here we head to the coast and to the Costa Brava – a wild Mediterranean paradise with its small white villages and beaches with crystal clear waters. It’s a great place for scuba diving or simply to enjoy a walk along the coast through the Camí de Ronda and take in the stunning coastline scenery.

A place of inspiration for many artists, Salvador Dalí is an important part of this area’s history. His house at Port Lligat is located within the Natural Park of Cap de Creus, a place of great natural beauty – beautiful beaches and mountains with routes where we can view various megalithic monuments, and one of the jewels of Romanesque art, the Monastery of St. Pere de Rodes.

Come and discover my homeland in a sustainable and mindful way. Connect with the region, its natural wonders, its gastronomic traditions, and culinary innovations, and enjoy the local handicrafts and outdoor activities.

2399.title: San Isidro Chronicles: The Gastronomy of Madrid
2399.excerpt: Food is at the heart of Spanish culture, from social life to business deals, everything revolves around food, and even more so in a city like Madrid.

flexible.wysiwyg:
And as with every Spanish fiesta there are traditional dishes that come to the fore. Let’s take a look at the origins of the food which has become synonymous with these celebrations.

As we discovered previously, these festivities are rooted in the pilgrimage to the ‘Meadowlands of San Isidro’, where there is chapel of the same name and where the Madrilenians go to venerate this saint (if you remember this was the place where San Isidro performed one of his first miracles). Another time we’ll talk about the routes we can do around Madrid linked to the life and miracles of San Isidro.

As we are talking fields out in the countryside, the typical dishes are more snack-like, but don’t, for that reason, underestimate how tasty they are. One of the most typical specialties of Madrid, and easy to eat at a picnic, is the calamari sandwich, with slices of squid fried in batter seasoned with a good squeeze of lemon. This dish can be traced back to the 16th century and the huge amount of fish that was brought into Madrid from the coast as a result of the Counter-Reformation and the restrictions on the consumption of meat on many dates (for example, during Lent) and so Madrid looked to other sources of food to keep itself going. As it would take several days to transport the fresh fish from the coast to the capital of Spain, the best options were the dried, smoked or salted fish.

Then, at the end of the 18th century, huge numbers of people migrated from Andalusia, Galicia and Asturias to Madrid who, first as kitchen staff and cooks in the homes of noble families and the bourgeoisie, and then later as owners of inns and taverns, served up the traditional dishes of their hometowns, based on different types of fish. Squid, which does not shrivel up and has no bones, fried in batter and seasoned with lemon (thus concealing any bad taste resulting from its journey to Madrid!), soon became a star of Madrid’s culinary tradition.
flexible.excerpt: As we are talking fields out in the countryside, the typical dishes are more snack-like, but don’t, for that reason, underestimate how tasty they are.

flexible.title: Squid, which does not shrivel up and has no bones, fried in batter and seasoned with lemon (thus concealing any bad taste resulting from its journey to Madrid!), soon became a star of Madrid's culinary tradition.

flexible.wysiwyg: Other typical dishes, and not only during the festival of San Isidro, are lamb ‘mesentery’ and suckling-pig intestines, or in more general culinary terms, dishes made from offal and organ meats. This type of cuisine, from more humble and rural origins, is present across the whole spectrum of Spanish gastronomy, from bull testicles and bull tail stew in Andalusia, to the blood cooked with onion in Murcia, as well as the huge tradition of sausages, black pudding and pâté. Madrid’s offal-based dishes normally consist of lamb entrails fried in suet. Strong in flavor, this dish is served during San Isidro in paper cones and sandwiches and, like ‘CALLOS MADRILEÑOS’ (beef tripe stew), has become in recent years something of a delicacy and is served in many high-end restaurants.

And we can’t finish without talking about the typical San Isidro ‘ROSQULLAS’ which are a type of doughnut. Their origin is the stuff of folklore, associated with Tía Javiera, who sold her doughnuts in the fields of San Isidro and who was so popular that the rest of the sellers claimed to be members and descendants of her family in order to sell their own doughnuts. There are four types of doughnut, which differ in their toppings: ‘las tontas’, with no topping; ‘las listas’ with sugar icing; the ‘Santa Clara’ ones, created by the Santa Clara nuns, topped with baked meringue; and the ‘French’ ones, so called because according to the story, the wife of Fernando VI, Bárbara de Braganza, asked the court cook, who was of French origin, to make them sweeter – these doughnuts are covered with almonds and icing sugar.

These doughnuts are so popular that they can be found in almost any pastry shop around the city and throughout the year, although the most famous ones are those from the ‘Antigua Pastelería del Pozo’. This cake shop was founded in 1830 and has the oldest ovens in Madrid.
flexible.excerpt: There is, therefore, no excuse to come to Madrid and not be pleasantly surprised by the city’s more traditional and popular cuisine.

related.post_title: Hidden Gems of Andalucía: Antequera, it’s a kind of magic
Easter in Spain or where passion meets art and tradition

2414.title: San Isidro Chronicles:  Goya in Madrid
2414.excerpt: If Madrid is a city full of art, culture and entertainment, the Fiestas of San Isidro, patron saint of the city, transform the capital of Spain into a festival of traditions, music, food and lots of fun.

flexible.wysiwyg:
The San Isidro festivities date back more than 500 years and commemorate the life and miracles of the Patron Saint of Madrid, Isidro Labrador, a peasant farmer by trade and a saint since 15 May, 1622, when he was canonized for his many water-related miracles (we will return to this another time to learn more about Madrid’s relationship with water and how you can make your way around this city visiting the sites of the saint’s miracles).

Tradition dictates that one should go on a pilgrimage to the chapel of San Isidro, located in the meadowlands bearing the same name.  There lies a spring with healing properties that the saint made flow up from the ground during a drought that was devastating the lands he was working for a local landowner. Goya, who arrived in Madrid when he was only 30 years old, knew exactly how to capture this pilgrimage and the popular festivities that took place here in these meadowlands at the end of the 18th century.

 

Goya, originally from Aragon, but more commonly associated with Madrid, often depicted the city’s most popular fiestas. This is what we find in tapestry designs, which Goya made under the supervision of Raphael Mengs, who at that time was the appointed painter of the Spanish court.

These designs are characterized by their picturesque and realistic style, in line with the fashion at that time and as dictated by the royal court. Goya’s work portrayed the cross section of Spanish society, both working class people and the aristocracy of the city, and their joy for life. These images of customs show us how the people of Madrid would dress during the San Isidro fiestas, as well as the games they used to play, and the dances they would dance. At a later date we will talk about the origin of the ‘majos’ and ‘chulapos’ – colorful figures and key to these celebrations.
flexible.excerpt: If Madrid is a city full of art, culture and entertainment, the Fiestas of San Isidro, patron saint of the city, transform the capital of Spain into a festival of traditions, music, food and lots of fun.

flexible.title: Madrid is art, and this art portrays its history, culture and traditions.

flexible.wysiwyg:
An excellent selection of these designs can be found at the Prado Museum, which exhibits the series of sketches and paintings that Goya made from 1775 to 1792 to decorate the Palaces of El Pardo and El Escorial, and that were destined for the Prince and Princess of Asturias, the future King Carlos IV and his consort María Luisa. Examples of this type of art can also be found at the lesser-known Royal Academy of Fine Arts of San Fernando, which houses works by the painter with other popular motifs such as bullfighting or the ‘burial of the sardine’, a festival where the people of Madrid bid farewell to the carnival period.

To delve deeper into the world of tapestries and to better understand the role this form of art has played in Madrid’s history, we must mention the Royal Tapestry Factory of Santa Barbara. A foundation since 1996, this venue both exhibits textile pieces designed by important painters, such as Goya, and promotes the conservation and restoration of Spain’s textile heritage. During a visit to this space we can see the textile craftsmen at work on their looms, creating tapestries, and carpets.

2868.title: San Isidro Cronicles: Following the steps of Madrid’s patron saint
2868.excerpt: Madrid is a city that can be discovered in many different ways: visiting the numerous museums, walking through the old center of Madrid of the Austrians, enjoying the Spanish tapas in taverns and inns… This time you will discover Madrid following the life and miracles of its patron saint, San Isidro Labrador.

flexible.wysiwyg:
As we saw before, this saint was a peasant farmer in the 12th century that performed many water-related miracles, and that was canonized on 15 May 1622, when he was also declared patron saint of Madrid. Saint Isidore was born in Madrid and he worked for a wealthy family of the Spanish nobility, the Vargas Family, whose house is located in La Latina neighborhood and where we can find the Saint Isidro Museum.

This museum, less famous than others like the Prado or the Thyssen-Bornemisza, is the house where this saint lived and die. The museum has a complete room dedicated to the life and miracles of this saint, but it is also focused on the history of Madrid and its development as city, covering from the Paleolithic period to the Modern Age. There you can find the original deep well, to which one of the most famous miracles of Saint Isidore is related. Legend has it that one day, while Isidore worked in the fields, his son fell into the well. When the father prayed to God, however, the water level rose, until it leveled with the curb, and the child appeared on the surface alive and well.

 

One of his other famous miracles is when Saint Isidore was working the lands of his landowner and he made flow up a spring from the ground during a drought. Tradition dictates that one should go on a pilgrimage to this spring, which has healing properties, and visit the Hermitage of Saint Isidore, located in the meadowlands bearing same name. This chapel was originally constructed under the order of the empress Isabella of Portugal in 1528, after his son, the future king Philip II, healed thanks to the spring. Since then, people go there on 15 May to drink the water of this healing spring and to worship the saint.

Another important tradition is the visit to the Chapel of Saint Isidore, which was erected in the ox stables, as a different miracle of the saint happened there. Legend has it that one morning the landlord went secretly to observe if Isidore was working the land, as the other workers had complained that he spent at prayer in church. The landlord saw two angels helping Isidore with the plowing, each angel leading a yoke of white oxen.
flexible.excerpt: Madrid is a city that can be discovered in many different ways: visiting the numerous museums, walking through the old center of Madrid of the Austrians, enjoying the Spanish tapas in taverns and inns… This time you will discover Madrid following the life and miracles of its patron saint, San Isidro Labrador.

flexible.title: Tradition dictates that one should go on a pilgrimage to this spring, which has healing properties, and visit the Hermitage of Saint Isidore, located in the meadowlands bearing same name.

flexible.wysiwyg:
However, the most important monument dedicated to this saint is, undoubtedly, the Collegiate Church of Saint Isidore, that contains the relics of Madrid’s patron saint and his wife, Santa María de la Cabeza. This Jesuit Baroque basilica church was built in the 17th century and it became the pro-cathedral of the city, until the current Almudena Cathedral was completed in 1993, when it returned to its collegiate status. A visit to this monument is always worthy, but it is much more during the festivities of San Isidro, as the carved images of both saints are taken out in procession around the streets.

In conclusion, the diversity of Madrid is endless and there are as many ways to visit this captivating city as you can imagine.

3031.title: El Camino de Santiago, a walk of life, through the camera lens
3031.excerpt: El Camino de Santiago, or The Way of Saint James using its name in English, is without a doubt one of those experiences one must do at least once in your lifetime. There is though, a recurring question that pops up all the time, and that is, why do it.

flexible.wysiwyg:
El Camino de Santiago, or The Way of Saint James using its name in English, is without a doubt one of those experiences one must do at least once in your lifetime. There is though, a recurring question that pops up all the time, and that is, why do it. For me, there has only been an answer for that: just because…

It is hard to know why we do the things we do, and even more difficult when it comes to walking a few hundred miles, getting blisters on your feet the size of a golf ball or enduring scorching desert heat one minute and getting soaking wet the next …

El Camino has inspired many pilgrims over the centuries, and despite the fact that this was a journey intended to find redemption for sins committed, nowadays it attracts people from all walks of life.

Some have wanted to leave us a testimony and a few have even filmed their “pilgrimage” in order to share this life changing and unique experience with the world. From fictional movies with Hollywood celebrities to spiritual documentaries narrating the inner journey of their protagonists, this is merely a small selection to get you going.

If you want to know why we love El Camino that much, get comfy, go fix some pop-corn and don’t forget pen and paper to write down the often-repeated words that will echo in your heads forever: alchemy, transformation, calling, freedom, simplicity, life metaphor, keep going, humility, purpose, compassion.…

Shoes, walking stick, action!
flexible.excerpt: If you want to know why we love El Camino that much, get comfy, go fix some pop-corn and don’t forget pen and paper to write down the often-repeated words that will echo in your heads forever: alchemy, transformation, calling, freedom, simplicity, life metaphor, keep going, humility, purpose, compassion.…

flexible.wysiwyg:
The Way (Fiction Movie. Filmax. 2010)

Official Trailer

This Hollywood movie is based on the actual Camino walk. Martin Sheen stars as Dr. Tom Avery, whose son Daniel died on the walk in the Pyrenees. It is funny but this role is played by his actual son Emilio Estevez, who wrote the story and directed it as well. Both father and son love Spain and have Spanish ancestors (Martin’s father was an immigrant from Galicia and he still keeps his real name Ramón Estevez on his passport)

This is a father-son story of redemption, forgiveness and adventure. “The Way” helps the audience grasp the basics of what el Camino de Santiago pilgrimage is about. It is a lot of fun to watch too. I am also tied to the film, as I assisted Emilio and the crew when they filmed across the region of La Rioja. I was able to meet and spend some time with Martin, Emilio and the rest of the production team and they even had my friend Leo and I play extras in the film, only to realize later on, we were just two blurry dots in the background of a scene where Martin Sheen gets all the attention and takes all credit. Oh well he was Mr. President after all 🙂

Footprints, the Path of your Life (Documentary. Netflix. 2016)

Official trailer

Father Sergio Fita is a devoted and dedicated Spanish catholic priest who lives in Mesa, Arizona. Looking for a greater purpose within his ministry, he put together a pilgrimage in the whole sense of the word. He gathered a bunch of young adults from his parish and offered them the chance to participate on a journey that millions of pilgrims had taken before them. His only promise to them was that of long hours of walking, very changeable weather conditions, a few blisters here and there, and a chance to find themselves and God along the way. Suffice to say, the stunning scenery of northern Spain, deepening their catholic roots and receiving plenary indulgence were also a bonus to consider.

The idea of producing and filming this was Juan Manuel Cotelo’s, and he directs this very personal and spiritual approach to El Camino. Then along came Netflix and this documentary became famous across the world.

The group walked along the less traveled path, the Northern Coastal route, which is pretty hard at times but hugely rewarding in terms of natural beauty. Cotelo does not present us with a road movie here, but rather an inner journey where you see the protagonists both endure and have the time of their lives. Through his exceptional spiritual guidance, Father Sergio created a sense of camaraderie and an unbreakable bond amongst the group. I was lucky to meet Father Sergio on one of my trips to Arizona and somehow become a part of this compassionate and moving story, one that has become the catalyst for many to embark on the adventure of walking El Camino de Santiago.

El Camino, Looking for Infinity (Documentary. Umbrella Entertainment. 2018)

Full Documentary

Aaron C. Leaman produced, directed and filmed this intriguing documentary on El Camino de Santiago. It is not intended to be either a travel guide or a history and culture aid to walk El Camino, but rather a sort of puzzle of emotions that anyone can relate to.

We all walk “El Camino” for some reason and in this documentary you will find the story behind almost all of them. From pilgrims trying to get back to God, or searching for Him, to more mystical approaches where nature and human beings are the thread that keep pulling forward you every step of “the way”. A multicultural melting pot, and it is interesting to feel how we start relating almost to all of the people walking across the screen. Wanting to be one of them. Longing to be one them.

El Camino has a very spiritual attraction to it, and the fact that you have to walk brings you somehow to a more human-like pace and dimension. We are meant to get from place to place on foot, and the world we live in nowadays has speeded up that process a million times over…

Even the fact that you may not relate to any of the many “peregrinos” in this documentary should be proof that you need to come and walk it no matter what!

O Apóstolo (3D Animation. 2012)

Official Trailer

As a bonus track to this article, O Apóstolo – “the Apostle” in Galician, is a very unique movie, being the first European 3D animation film.

Filmed by Fernando Cortizo, and using the complex and time consuming “stop motion” technique, O Apóstolo simultaneously presents a very funny and mysterious approach to the rural Galician landscape, where El Camino serves as the backbone to this spooky story. It was awarded a Goya in Spain for best animation film (Goyas are the Spanish equivalent to the Oscars) and for the Spanish audience it was fantastic to have well-known local Spanish actors lending their voices to the film’s characters.

Galicians are well known for their ambiguity and maybe-yes-or-no answers to any type of question. When prompted about whether witches exist or not (called “meigas” in Galician) they always reply with a “well…maybe, just in case”

So enjoy El Camino, just never walk it alone or in the dark, just in case… 🙂

3053.title: The Spanish expedition against the smallpox pandemic
3053.excerpt: Galicia is a beautiful, enigmatic region, open to the sea: a wild, unpredictable sea that has plotted the course of its destiny. This corner of Spain has an important Celtic heritage mingled with the hallmark left by the Camino de Santiago.

flexible.title:
When a piece of history is a great story series:
This logbook is about those historical moments when a tiny place in Spain or Portugal became universal. Because sometimes fortuitous facts or apparently insignificant people change the course of history, just like a butterfly flapping can cause a hurricane.

flexible.wysiwyg:
At the beginning of the 19th C. the Balmis expedition departed from the harbour of A Coruña (Galicia, Northern Spain) carrying the smallpox vaccine to the New World territories. On board, 22 children from the city’s orphanage were successively inoculated during the journey to Puerto Rico in order to transmit the vaccine alive in their own bodies.

The ancient Roman lighthouse of A Coruña (the oldest lighthouse in use, built in the 2nd C. and a UNESCO World Heritage Site) has witnessed several historical events from its prominent position facing the Atlantic Ocean. But right here we want to share with you this specific episode because of its significance in present times: a handful of hope in the middle of a global crisis.

 

Galicia is a beautiful, enigmatic region, open to the sea: a wild, unpredictable sea that has plotted the course of its destiny. This corner of Spain has an important Celtic heritage mingled with the hallmark left by the Camino de Santiago.

 

 

 

 

Galician people have migrated overseas more than any other people in Spain (excepting Basques, perhaps). And they took with them their culture and customs, their language (gallego) and their morriña: this Galician word, without a clear translation into any other language, refers to the nostalgia we feel from a homeland that is left behind.

 

The protagonists of this event also migrated from Galicia to the New World: this group of brave people achieved a milestone in the history of medicine with the first vaccination campaign in history.

 

In the 18th C. smallpox was a devastating disease that was spreading death all over the world. Up until an English physician, Dr. Edward Jenner, discovered that cowpox, a much benigner version of smallpox that affected cattle, caused immunity in humans. However, as the vaccine could not be synthesized, the only way to transport it was by transmitting the infection from one subject to another.

 

And then again, the world is a big place. 

 

So when Dr. Francisco Javier de Balmis came up with the idea of an expedition to America to spread the smallpox vaccination, it probably sounded kind of crazy in the court of king Charles IV of Spain. Yet he managed to convince the king and to find the “volunteering” subjects that would embark on the ship María Pita from A Coruña to San Juan de Puerto Rico: 22 orphan children from A Coruña, who maintained the fluid alive in their bodies, being inoculated consecutively, from one arm to the other, during the course of the navigation. A group of doctors and nurses, including the rectoress of the orphanage, Isabel Zendal, accompanied and cared for the children during the journey. Every time the ship docked at a port, new local children were inoculated. In this way the vaccine arrived at the Canary Islands and Puerto Rico, and from there it progressively expanded to North and South America, the Philippines and Southern Asia. The first international healthcare expedition in history had been a success and millions of lives were saved.

 

Independent of the obvious ethical questions raised by such a plan, the courage and presence of mind shown by Dr. Balmis sent an inspiring message whose meaning is just as valid today as two centuries ago: one brilliant idea and the determination to carry it out are enough to make a difference.

 

Sources:

  • National Geographic Historia

https://historia.nationalgeographic.com.es/a/expedicion-balmis-ninos-que-llevaron-vacuna-viruela-a-america_15225

3074.title: Tordesillas: the Treaty to divide the world between two empires
3074.excerpt: Close to Salamanca, cradle of the first university of Spain (and  the third western university, after Bologna and Paris) and whose old city is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Tordesillas is also next to important wine regions such as D.O. Ribera del Duero, D.O. Rueda and D.O. Toro.  Even if the name does not sound familiar to you, the area possesses a bunch of musts and definitely deserves a place in our Collection.

flexible.title:
When a piece of history is a great story series:
In 1494 the two superpowers of the time, namely Spain and Portugal, faced each other at the small Castilian town of Tordesillas in order to reach an agreement meant to divide the newly-discovered lands outside Europe between them. The border was set along a meridian 370 leagues west of Cape Verde islands in West Africa.

flexible.wysiwyg:
Tordesillas is just a small town in Castile, a Spanish region defined by a low population rate and a notably rural character. A private joke among Spain Collection’s curators considers Castile as “the Spanish Wisconsin”. Yet Castile gave name once to an empire “on which the sun never sets”. 

 

The place is close to Salamanca, cradle of the first university of Spain (and  the third western university, after Bologna and Paris) and whose old city is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Tordesillas is also next to important wine regions such as D.O. Ribera del Duero, D.O. Rueda and D.O. Toro.  Even if the name does not sound familiar to you, the area possesses a bunch of musts and definitely deserves a place in our Collection.   

However, it is thanks to the signing of the Treaty of Tordesillas between the Portuguese and the Spanish that this little town went down in the annals of History.

 

Christopher Columbus, who had been commissioned by the Crown of Castile for his first trip to America and navigated under Castile’s flag, docked at Lisbon on his way back and gave accounts of his discovery to the king of Portugal John II. The Portuguese king didn’t like the fact that Castile had scored a coup in the battle for conquering the world. Kings are not fond of that kind of things. Portugal was especially interested (and thus concerned) about India, Guinea and the kingdom of Fez, and considering that in those times it wasn’t that easy to determine which parallels or meridians had been crossed or where was the land they had discovered (Columbus thought that the island they had arrived at was in East Asia), we can easily understand the monarch’s preoccupation. 

 

Consequently Portugal claimed the new land according to the Treaty of Alcáçovas and the confrontation turned into a diplomatic combat where pope Alexander VI (Rodrigo Borgia, born in Valencia, Crown of Aragon) clearly took the Spanish side by issuing several papal bulls that granted the new-found territories to the Spanish Catholic Monarchs. The Treaty of Tordesillas came up to solve the conflict (at least for a time) by laying an imaginary line from pole to pole 370 west of Cape Verde: the territories to the west were granted to Spain, the territories to the east to Portugal.

 

A stroll through Tordesillas will show the mediaeval flair of this village: the so-called “Houses of Treaty”, where the agreement was signed (a disputed fact, as some scholars considers that the location was most likely the town’s Royal Palace, today disappeared), the Church of San Antolin and the Convent of Santa Clara, where Queen Joanna of Castile and Aragon was confined by her father King Ferdinand of Aragon as a strategy to block her legal birthrights.

 

Sources:

  • National Geographic Historia

https://historia.nationalgeographic.com.es/a/donde-se-firmo-tratado-tordesillas_14924

  • Archivos Historia

https://archivoshistoria.com/el-tratado-de-tordesillas-un-error-de-castilla/

3137.title: Sustainable Michelin Star Restaurants in Spain
3137.excerpt: Spain is undoubtedly one of the most foodie countries in the world, a gastronomic reference because of its tradition, the high quality of the products and the famous Mediterranean diet which is one of the healthiest.

flexible.title: “We believe in a world where our responsibility is to work as guardians of what is received, of that nature that surrounds us and that we must protect. We use our knowledge for social well-being, adapting to people's needs” Azurmendi Restaurant

flexible.wysiwyg:
It seems clear that 2021 is a year of change: a year to regenerate, to reinvent and redefine everything. After this pandemic, nothing will be the same, especially in the way we travel.

We are more concerned than ever about the problems that we, as humans, cause to our planet – which is not only our home, but also the future generations’ home -. Right now the word “sustainability” appears on every organization’s agenda, applied to every kind of industry. However, some voices consider this term as obsolete and rather emphasize on the concept of “regeneration”.

With regards to the gastronomic world, the distinguished, widely known Michelin Guide has been focused during the last years on rewarding and recognizing those chefs and restaurants committed to the global topic of sustainability. Their way is based on the classical premise “think globally, act locally”, supporting the local community and remaining loyal to human values. 

 

The Michelin Guide Spain & Portugal 2021 Gala became a landmark for environmental regeneration through gastronomy: 21 Spanish restaurants were awarded for the first time with a Green Michelin Star. This recognition is dedicated to those restaurants that promote environmentally friendly, innovative practices and consider sustainability as a central part of their agenda. 

 

Among them we find the 3-star Michelin restaurant Azurmendi and the 1-star Michelin restaurant Eneko, both in the Basque Country and both led by the talentive chef Eneko Atxa. Azurmendi, in particular, was awarded in 2018 as the “Most Sustainable Restaurant in the World” by “The World’s 50 Best”.

 

Another prominent example is the 3-star Michelin restaurant Aponiente, in the south of Spain, led by the revolutionary chef Ángel León, who is committed to the sea in every single detail: his cuisine comes from the sea, honors the sea and the biodiversity treasured in the oceans.

 

We, Spain Collection’s curators, as proud spokespersons of Spain, the foodie nation par excellence, will be delighted to introduce you to the unique gourmet experiences our land can offer. Just have look to a few of our food & wine collections through this link

flexible.title: “We know that we’re not going to change the world, however, through the “Cooks for Sustainability” initiative, we can reflect and share ideas based on good environmental practice that can translate into a real intention for change.” Angel Leon, Aponiente Restaurant.

563.title: The captivating magic of the Alhambra
563.excerpt: We take you on a visit of this World Heritage Site once its doors have closed to the public. As the day draws to a close, you will have two hours journey back in time with the help of our expert guide. It is a magical experience, a feast for the senses with its sumptuous […]
563.content: We take you on a visit of this World Heritage Site once its doors have closed to the public. As the day draws to a close, you will have two hours journey back in time with the help of our expert guide. It is a magical experience, a feast for the senses with its sumptuous interiors, the multi-colored tiles, its patios, arcades and corridors and windows that filter the light, the water channels that flow under your feet, the lush vegetation and the bubbling of the fountains and ponds, make it a paradise that has wowed visitors over the centuries.

fields.intro: The majestic Alhambra, the jewel in the crown of Granada’s Moorish past, is arguably one of the most impressive sites you will ever visit in your life!
fields.intro_mobile: The majestic Alhambra, the jewel in the crown of Granada’s Moorish...

flexible.wysiwyg: Let us take you on a visit to this World Heritage Site once its doors have closed to the public. As the day draws to a close, journey back in time with the help of our expert guide, with the Alhambra all yours for a couple of hours. It’s a wondrous experience, a feast for the senses with its multicolored tiles, its exquisite patios, arcades and corridors, and windows that filter the light in a magical way; the lush vegetation and the bubbling of the fountains and water channels that flow under your feet… perhaps you are closer now to understanding how this place has never ceased to wow visitors over the centuries.

Why not go a step further – choose a subject that fascinates you, such as the decorated tiles, the vegetation or the importance of AGUA (water) within the palace and we will organise for a local expert to give you a ‘master class’ in your chosen topic prior to your visit. This experience further enhances your tour as you better understand the whys and wherefores of this architectural masterpiece. This is also a wonderful experience for families.

All curious travellers keep Granada in their hearts, even without having visited it.

William Shakespeare. English writer (1564-1616).

fields.intro: Following the overthrow of his family (the Umayyads) in Syria, Prince Abd al- Rahman escaped to Spain and attempted to recreate the grandeur of Damascus in his new capital, Cordoba. He wanted to make the Mosque a place of pilgrimage, a Mecca for the western world.
fields.intro_mobile: Following the overthrow of his family (the Umayyads) in Syria, Prince Abd al- Rahman escaped to Spain and attempted to recreate the grandeur of Damascus in his new capital, Cordoba. He wanted to make the Mosque a place of pilgrimage, a Mecca for the western world.

flexible.wysiwyg:
The Mosque-Cathedral of Cordoba is one of the most amazing monuments in the world.  Its stunning architecture tells the story of the city’s past as the capital of Islamic Spain. A World Heritage site since 1984, this huge building dominates the old town that surrounds it. At its height, in the 10th century, the mosque was the center of Western Islam and a cultural hub that rivalled Baghdad and Constantinople.  The Christians arrived in 1236, and there now stands a Gothic Cathedral in the CORAZÓN (heart) of the mosque.

Visit this fascinating site behind closed doors, at the end of opening hours to the public. An official guide, specialised in the history of the monument, will share with you the essence of its unique history and the different civilizations that passed through here.

To complement this visit, a group of local musicians will add to the experience by performing various Arabic and Christian pieces, the music corresponding to the different periods of the building’s history.  It is worth noting that during the Caliphate of Cordoba, this city saw the birth of what can be considered the first Music Conservatory in Europe, thanks to the famous artist Ziryab; the fusion of Arabic and Christian sounds and instruments is something quite extraordinary.

 

Legend has it that the city is the birthplace of flamenco.

Everything is possible in Cordoba.

 

 

“Cordoba with its old houses with the Mosque where your glance is lost in the middle of those wonderful views”

Victor Hugo.French writer.1802-1885

978.title: The cities of 3 cultures: Cordoba, Granada and Toledo

experiences.name: Religious Heritage
experiences.description: The Knights Templar, the Jesuits, Islam, the Sephardic legacy, the history of the Moors, none of these can be studied or better understood without setting foot in Spain or Portugal.

destinations.name: Andalusia
destinations.description: Andalusia is passion personified. Often portrayed as encapsulating the essence and spirit of Spain with its sun-dappled white villages and ...

fields.intro: When thinking of Spain and its history, the ‘city of three cultures’ usually refers to Toledo. However Toledo is not the only place where traces of the three cultures remain. You can see this in other places around the country, such as Cordoba and Granada in Andalusia. Muslims, Christians and Jews coexisted for over 7 centuries on the Iberian Peninsula.
fields.intro_mobile: When thinking of Spain and its history, the ‘city of three cultures’ usually refers to Toledo. However Toledo is not the only place where traces of the three cultures remain. You can see this in other places around the country, such as Cordoba and Granada in Andalusia. Muslims, Christians and Jews coexisted for over 7 centuries on the Iberian Peninsula.

flexible.wysiwyg:
Despite centuries of war and disputes over land and God, the three most important monotheistic religions, Judaism, Islam and Christianity have lived and coexisted in a relative state of peace for hundreds of years in Spain. CONVIVENCIA, meaning living together, is a beautiful word in Spanish, coined to describe that state of cultural convergence and the intertwining of traditions that permeated all fields of knowledge, from art to science, and from architecture to cooking.

Let our curators accompany you to UNESCO gems such as Cordoba or Granada, and beyond Andalusia, to Toledo near Madrid. These 3 places still preserve the very essence of the three cultures in their medieval quarters. This ‘convivencia’ created a melting pot where Muslim art was incorporated into Jewish buildings which were then turned into Christian churches, like the Transito Synagogue in Toledo or in Cordoba, where we find a Gothic Catholic cathedral literally embedded in a former mosque.

Tolerance implies no lack of commitment to one’s own beliefs. Rather it condemns the oppression or persecution of others “

John F. Kennedy, President of the United States of America (1917-1963)

With our historians and local insiders, we will untangle centuries of Sephardic Jewish heritage in Toledo, feast our eyes on the blast of colors of the Andalusian patios in Cordoba, and wander around the magical gardens and fountains of the Alhambra Palace in Granada. The history of these three spectacular cities will help you better understand the spirituality and traditions that still hold strong in Spain today.

fields.intro: The General Archive of the Indies in Seville was created in 1785 by King Carlos III. The aim was to centralize, under one roof, the documentation relating to the governance of the Spanish colonies which until then had been kept in various archives in Simancas, Cádiz and Seville.
fields.intro_mobile: The General Archive of the Indies in Seville was created in 1785 by King Carlos III. The aim was to centralize, under one roof, the documentation relating to the governance of the Spanish colonies which until then had been kept in various archives in Simancas, Cádiz and Seville.

flexible.wysiwyg: The history of Spain and Portugal is simply fascinating and at the impressive General Archive of the Indies in Seville you can study the documents and maps that marked the evolution of the history of these two countries. This archive is the largest collection of historical documents that exists in Spain and it details the commercial transactions between the Spanish crown and the colonies of the New World and the Philippines. This archive takes over from the one founded in the 16th century by Charles I of Castile in the town of Simancas. Accompanied by one of our historians, lose yourself among millions of pages of history incalculable value, and immerse yourself the 800 plus old maps that are preserved in this unique place. We will not only learn about the content of the maps, but also, under the guidance of our curators, learn how to classify and consult the documents or read the handwritten CARTAS (letters) of some of the greatest navigators in history, such as Christopher Columbus or the Portuguese, Fernando de Magellan.

This very special visit is the perfect conclusion to a city tour where you will visit the Royal Alcazar where the Catholic Kings lived for 8 years and gave Columbus the required funds for his journey to the Indies, and the ‘Torre del Oro’ (Golden Tower) where the vast amount of gold from the New World was stored upon arrival in Spain.

You can never cross the ocean unless you have the courage to lose sight of the shore

Christopher Columbus, Explorer (1451-1499)

fields.intro_mobile: Cadiz sits on a narrow slice of land surrounded by the sea. It's small, colourful and wonderful like a box of chocolates. It’s a must-do if you love history, art, food and sunshine. Remember the best things come in small packages!

flexible.wysiwyg: Cadiz is considered one of the oldest cities in western Europe, so its cultural heritage is rich and immense. With this in mind, we have created a unique tour, full of surprises, for lovers of art in all its forms.  Besides the wonderful Baroque and Delft tiles behind hidden doorways, we will also have private access to museums with art historians who will reveal the secrets behind the paint strokes of Goya, the ‘Caprichos’.  There is also the opportunity to lose yourself in some of the most important private ARCHIVOS (archives) of the country, enjoy the aroma of the ‘incunabula’ and marvel at some of the most wonderfully bound books in the world.

All these treasures, which have been preserved thanks to the silent work of philanthropists and collectors, are housed within buildings from the 15th and 18th centuries and are not available to the average traveller. Trust Spain Collection and our unrivalled contacts for an exclusive insider’s experience.

 

Sea where thoughts sail at will, without ever reaching any shore (mar donde el pensamiento navega a su antojo sin llegar a ninguna orilla)

Benito Pérez Galdós. Writer (1843-1920).

fields.intro: Cadiz is a magical place surrounded by the sea. It’s a romantic jumble of winding streets, music, and 'joie de vivre'. The people are warm and welcoming, and the food is fabulous.  Come experience it for yourself!
fields.intro_mobile: Cadiz is a magical place surrounded by the sea. It’s a romantic jumble of winding streets, music, and 'joie de vivre'. The people are warm and welcoming, and the food is fabulous.  Come experience it for yourself!

flexible.wysiwyg:
Cadiz is one of the oldest cities in Europe. Civilizations such as the Phoenicians, Romans and Arabs have all left their mark, but without a doubt its most golden era was in the 18th century, when its port became one of the most important in the world thanks to trade with America.

 

Journey with us in time, to a time of cultural splendour, to a small port that transformed into a great cosmopolitan city, where all languages were spoken and the opening nights for operas happened here before transferring to the capital, Madrid.  Even Joseph Haydn composed one of his masterpieces, ‘The Seven Words’, in honour of the city, thanks to a commission by the Marquis of Valde-Íñigo.

 

Feel part of Cadiz SOCIEDAD (society) as you enjoy the hospitality of the descendants of some of the oldest local families, who, for generations, have treasured and preserved works of art, books, and décor that bore witness to this golden moment in this city’s history.

For music lovers we can organise an evening with the selected works performed by a soprano or a tenor, or if you prefer the flamenco rhythms, some ‘Alegrías de Cádiz’, the typical flamenco form from this area of Andalusia.  This bespoke experience can also include local wines and food whilst your local hosts explain and share the essence of their way of life.

 

Cádiz is a city of magic, like Cracow or Dublin, to set the mind on fire at a turn of a corner…The eye is continually fed, the imagination stirred, by a train of spectacles as charming as if they had been contrived

Honor Tracy. Writer.1913-1989

related.post_content: We take you on a visit of this World Heritage Site once its doors have closed to the public. As the day draws to a close, you will have two hours journey back in time with the help of our expert guide. It is a magical experience, a feast for the senses with its sumptuous interiors, the multi-colored tiles, its patios, arcades and corridors and windows that filter the light, the water channels that flow under your feet, the lush vegetation and the bubbling of the fountains and ponds, make it a paradise that has wowed visitors over the centuries.

fields.intro: Bluefin tuna, or ‘red tuna’ as it is known in Spanish, is caught as it travels from the Atlantic to the Mediterranean to lay its eggs in warmer waters, using the ‘almadraba’ (nest) trap system. The fishing of tuna has existed since the times of the Phoenicians. The tuna has always been highly prized, and this sought-after culinary gem is waiting for you.
fields.intro_mobile: Bluefin tuna, or ‘red tuna’ as it is known in Spanish, is caught as it travels from the Atlantic to the Mediterranean to lay its eggs in warmer waters, using the ‘almadraba’ (nest) trap system. The fishing of tuna has existed since the times of the Phoenicians. The tuna has always been highly prized, and this sought-after culinary gem is waiting for you.

flexible.wysiwyg:
Cadiz, the southernmost city of Europe, is famous for its bluefin tuna fishing. The fishing is done using traditional ALMADRABAS – an authentic labyrinth of nets – which are placed in strategic points near the Strait of Gibraltar. The same strategic fishing points have been used for thousands of years.

The art of RONQUEO, which refers to the noise made by the knife of the RONQUEADOR as it is dragged along the spine of the fish (a type of buzzing noise), is the process of cutting up the tuna. It is both a delicate and brutal ritual, something to behold. Absolutely all parts of the tuna are used, nose to tail, nothing is wasted. The ‘ronqueadores’ are known for their strong hands and their incredible precision as they break-down the huge tuna.

Carriazo was a rogue, he worked in the ALMADRABAS in Zahara (Cadiz).

Extract from “The Illustrious Kitchen Maid”.

Miguel de Cervantes y Saavedra.Writer (1547-1616)

We can combine a ‘ronqueo’ and a tasting of the tuna with a visit of the archaeological remains of one of the Roman towns that sprung up around the fishing industry. At the ruins of ‘Baelo Claudia’ we can see the remains of a ‘Garum’ (sauce) and fish-salting factory which is located on one of the most impressive beaches on the Andalusian coastline.

Wrap this experience up with a meal at Aponiente, Ángel León’s remarkable three-Michelin-star restaurant which showcases his unique ‘cuisine of the sea’. Ángel León was a sailor before becoming a chef and his love of the sea is a huge feature of his cuisine. He is widely regarded as one of the most outstandingly creative chefs in the country.

fields.intro: Old taverns keep alive the magical ambience and taste of old Seville. Enjoying their popular and delicious tapas will take you back in time, to the very roots of our traditions.
fields.intro_mobile: Old taverns keep alive the magical ambience and taste of old Seville. Enjoying their popular and delicious tapas will take you back in time, to the very roots of our traditions.

flexible.wysiwyg:
The gastronomic world of Seville is a cacophony of colour, joy and magic much in the same spirit as the city itself. Make your way round the old bars, taverns and wine cellars on a very special tapas route within the area declared a World Heritage site in 1987.

A local gastronomy expert will accompany you on this culinary experience where you will have the opportunity to try the best JAMONES (hams), cheeses and stews paired with the best Andalusian wines, with the ever-present flamenco guitar in the background.

If the countryside is more your thing, we can leave the city behind and head to a centuries-old, typical Andalusian CORTIJO (farmhouse) with courtyards full of flowers and spacious, white-washed rooms filled with antiques.  You will feel as if you have been transported to a different world and to a different era. These typical homesteads are iconic of Andalusia, and they have always been beating the heart of the farming industry here.

 

The cuisine here is mouth-wateringly simple, as traditional as they are full of flavour. Sit at the dining table of our host to eat and wonder at all the life that has passed before. Close your eyes and listen to the stories of families that have lived here for generations, breathe in the multitude of smells of the countryside, and feel the hypnotic beat of flamenco…

 

Seville is a towerful of fine archers…

Under the arch of the sky, across the clear plain, she shoots the constant arrow of the river.

Federico García Lorca.Writer and poet, (1898-1936).

fields.intro: The wine region of Jerez is a destination full of sensorial experiences. Each drop of wine is divine.
fields.intro_mobile: The wine region of Jerez is a destination full of sensorial experiences. Each drop of wine is divine.

flexible.wysiwyg:
Spain is a paradise for wine lovers, with a total of 96 ‘Denominations of Origin’ or ‘D.O.’  The D.O. ‘Jerez Sherry’ is the oldest in Spain, dating back to 1930.  Yet recent archaeological discoveries have found a Phoenician winery in this area of southern Spain, which could potentially make it one of the oldest in Europe.

 

Jerez is also famous for its ‘Tabancos’ – a particular style of tavern which can be traced back to the 17th century.  They serve bulk-bought, local sherry wines straight from the cask. Background music is usually provided by local flamenco musicians, and of course, there’s the food in the shape of truly delicious tapas.  Accompanied by a local winemaker or a top ‘sommelier’, you can learn to VENECIAR (the art of serving a glass of wine to oxygenate it) whilst sampling different types of wine and hearing the stories behind some of the region’s most famous vineyards.

If penicillin can cure those that are ill, Spanish sherry can bring the dead back to life

Alexander Fleming, Physician and Microbiologist (1881-1955)
