fields.intro: A horse is much more than an animal, they bring a sense of calm. Our world would not be the same without them. Experience the essential joy that being with these gorgeous creatures brings to your soul.
fields.intro_mobile: A horse is much more than an animal, they bring a sense of calm. Our world would not be the same without them. Experience the essential joy that being with these gorgeous creatures brings to your soul.

flexible.wysiwyg:
The Andalusian horse originates from the rugged, hilly areas of the Iberian Peninsula and is one of the world’s most ancient horse breeds. The Andalusian horse was developed in southern Spain when King Felipe II founded the ‘Caballerizas Reales de Córdoba’ (Royal Stables of Cordoba). They were originally highly regarded as a cavalry horse due to their agility and courage. Today the Andalusian CABALLO (horse) is used as a general riding horse, for bullfighting, dressage, classical riding and high school work. A visit to these stables is like setting foot in a most extraordinary universe.

 

In Jerez de la Frontera, the ‘Yeguada de la Cartuja’ is considered the most important Carthusian stud farm and horse reserve in the world. The ‘Cartujano Horse’ is considered the elite of the purebred Spanish horses, and a visit here is a ‘must’ for any horse lover. You will be able to observe these noble animals up close, and meet their riders and trainers.

Another ‘temple’ for any horse lover is the Royal Andalusian School of Equestrian Art located in a 19th century palace in Jerez. The facilities are surrounded by beautiful gardens where we will also find the stables and a fascinating museum. Enjoy a captivating performance of ‘How the Andalusian Horses Dance’, which showcases different types of dressage set to the beat of flamenco, whilst sampling sherry: this unique experience pairs five of the region’s top sherries with five movements of the horse, the fusion of the elegance of the animal and the taste of our land.

No hour of life is wasted that is spent in the saddle

Winston Churchill. Politician, military officer and writer.(1874-1965).

fields.intro: People go to El Rocio all year round, people who believe in heaven and those who don’t. After a few hours on this most Spanish of pilgrimages you start to feel a certain connection to the place, to the spirit of the people and to the essence of this tradition.
fields.intro_mobile: People go to El Rocio all year round, people who believe in heaven and those who don’t. After a few hours on this most Spanish of pilgrimages you start to feel a certain connection to the place, to the spirit of the people and to the essence of this tradition.

flexible.wysiwyg:
To know Andalusia is to know its traditions.

 

Visit one of the most special corners of this region of Spain: the tiny village of ‘El Rocio’, in Huelva, where the streets are covered with sand because there are more horses than cars on them, and where flamenco, joy and tradition abound in flouncy dresses and little flowery shawls.

 

The small, white houses of the village surround the famous church known as the ‘Ermita de la Virgen del Rocío’. The statue of the Virgin Mary here has been venerated for centuries and attracts more than a million visitors each year, making it one of the most important Marian pilgrimages in the world.

Spend time with a local family who will welcome you into their home. Learn about their devotion to the Virgin, whom they call ‘The White Dove’. Have private lessons in the typical dance of the area, ‘la sevillana’. Learn the basic steps of the dance to the rhythm of a guitar and the songs of a flamenco group.

 

Learn how to make a ‘salmorejo’ or a ‘tortilla de patatas’ in the family kitchen. Share a meal with your hosts and enjoy some ‘pata negra’ ham and sample the local wines and other traditional dishes.

 

Wrap up the day enjoying the views of Doñana National Park, which surrounds the PUEBLO (village).  Here horses graze freely and birds like the pink flamingo nest.

Without a doubt, an unforgettable experience.

 

Let the world be ROCIEROS

Pope John Paul II,s.(1978-2005)

1086.title: Horse Racing on the Beach at Sanlucar de Barrameda

fields.intro: Watch the thrilling spectacle of horses thundering down a beach. An experience made even better when accompanied by an ice-cold Manzanilla and some perfectly grilled fresh prawns.
fields.intro_mobile: Watch the thrilling spectacle of horses thundering down a beach. An experience made even better when accompanied by an ice-cold Manzanilla and some perfectly grilled fresh prawns.

flexible.wysiwyg:
Every year, over the first 2 weekends of August, the small seaside town of Sanlúcar de Barrameda becomes the venue for one of the biggest society events of the year.  The low tide turns the beach into a racetrack for one of the oldest and most singular horse races held in Europe. These races have been happening here since 1845.

Sanlucar is also famous for its JEREZ (sherry) and is the favoured tipple at the races. The ‘Manzanilla de Sanlucar’ is one of the most renowned wines of the D.O. Jerez, and is only produced here in this town. The wine pairs wonderfully with the prawns that are fished in this area. So, as with any ‘fiesta’, the gastronomy that accompanies the event is of equal importance!

Kick off a visit to this area of the world at one of the farms where the famous ‘Pura Raza Española’, one of the most prized horses in the world, is bred. A guided tour sheds light on the importance of this animal to the region of Andalusia. See a dressage training session and, if you wish, participate in an exercise putting these beautiful animals through their paces.

Then we head to the races from a spot which guarantees the best views of the action. Enjoy the fun whilst contemplating one of the most spectacular sunsets you can imagine, with a glass of Manzanilla de Sanlúcar in one hand and tapas of some local speciality in the other!

 

The history of mankind is carried on the back of a horse.

Author Unknown,

fields.intro: Indulge your passion for speed and get behind the wheel of something fast and luxurious!
fields.intro_mobile: Indulge your passion for speed and get behind the wheel of something fast and luxurious!

flexible.wysiwyg:
Lying in the glorious sunshine just a bit too slow-paced for you? Then head to the racetrack with a team of professional instructors waiting for you! Andalusia has some of the most famous racetracks in the world, from Jerez de la Frontera, which is full of local character and a firm favorite with fans from across the world, to the fabulous private facilities at Ascari, located in the foothills of Marbella.

 

We can get you special access to race events, pit-lane access and ‘meet & greet’ with some of the stars of the motor-sporting world. Or we can get your adrenaline pumping by arranging something closer to the action, something that allows you feel the power of 700 HP roaring under the hood of a Lamborghini, or let our driving pros teach you how to drift a Porsche Carrera like they do in the movies.

To cool off, drive some of the region’s most scenic roads and then enjoy the sunset parked up at one of the coast’s most exclusive yacht clubs and chill-out with a cocktail on a TERRAZA (terrace).

Shaken, not stirred!

James Bond, Secret Intelligence Service Officer

fields.intro: Gone with the wind! Tarifa is where water sports lovers head to. Pristine waters, a wonderful climate and the best wind in Europe.
fields.intro_mobile: Gone with the wind! Tarifa is where water sports lovers head to. Pristine waters, a wonderful climate and the best wind in Europe.

flexible.wysiwyg:
If you love surfing or kitesurfing, Tarifa ‘the capital of the wind’, is the place to go.

Tarifa is located in the province of Cádiz, at the southernmost point of Spain, where the land juts out into both the Mediterranean Sea and the Atlantic Ocean. Both bodies of water lap at its coast, so it is quite a unique place to visit. It is also 8.9 miles away from continental Africa. In fact, it’s so close that it’s possible to see the African coastline from Tarifa’s beautiful beaches.

There are two types of wind in Tarifa: the windsurfer-friendly ‘Levante’ (dry, warm wind coming from the east), and the ‘Poniente’ (colder wind off the sea from the west), which blows in from the west, it’s also colder because it comes from the sea), which is best for kite surfers. The mecca of kitesurf, this area enjoys an average of 300 days of sun and wind per year. So, who can really resist the calling of the sun, surf and sand?

Take private lessons with a top qualified teacher. There is a ‘kite beach’ which doesn’t allow people to swim in the sea so there’s something less to worry about!

This activity is suitable both for children and adults, so it’s a great opportunity to spend quality time, at a gorgeous spot, with friends and family.

Tarifa village is very pretty, with lots of monuments and historical sites to visit. The Guzmán el Bueno Castle is the most important historical site. It dates back to the 10th century, when it was built on the orders of the Caliph of Córdoba to protect the town from invaders. It’s named after Alonso Perez de Guzman, the commander who defended Tarifa from a Moorish siege in 1294, sacrificing his own son in the process.

Needless to say, the food here is amazing especially if you love fresh bluefin tuna or seafood.

 

The town of Tarifa symbolizes the beginning of a journey

Paulo Coelho.Writer.Born in 1947.

fields.intro: There is no better place to experience the excitement and sophistication of one of the oldest team sports in the world than at the 'Wimbledon of Polo Pitches'.
fields.intro_mobile: There is no better place to experience the excitement and sophistication of one of the oldest team sports in the world than at the 'Wimbledon of Polo Pitches'.

flexible.wysiwyg:
Sotogrande located in the province of Cadiz, is the largest, privately-owned, residential development in Andalusia. In the early 1960s Joseph McMicking, an American hailing from Scottish and Filipino parentage, had the foresight to create what is now one of the most exclusive resorts in Spain.

McMicking attended Stanford University and was inspired by the Pebble Beach resort in California. Polo came to Sotogrande thanks to him and his wife Mercedes Zobel de Ayala y Roxas. The famous grounds of Sotogrande have long been considered the ‘Wimbledon of Polo Pitches’, as they are considered to be the best in the world thanks in part to their location, being surrounded by tropical gardens, their close proximity to the sea close and sitting under endless blue skies.

Field polo is very much still classified as a sport for the wealthy, with players from the international jet set visiting from all over the world to play throughout the year. After watching the game, you might be tempted to get on a horse and try out this sport for yourself! Spain Collection gives you the opportunity to try, whether you have horse-riding experience or not. Learn the basic rules of the game from highly qualified players.

The day will end with an exhibition match, with commentary by a Polo professional. See what you have learned and put into action out on the field.

Wrap up your day with a fantastic Argentinian-style barbecue. A truly memorable day for sure!

 

A Polo handicap is a person’s ticket to the world

Winston Churchill, Statesman, 1874-1965

fields.intro: Discover the world of olives, one of the most valuable foods in the world and pillar of our Mediterranean diet. Learn how they are harvested and processed, and enjoy a banquet at an authentic Renaissance palace!
fields.intro_mobile: Discover the world of olives, one of the most valuable foods in the world and pillar of our Mediterranean diet. Learn how they are harvested and processed, and enjoy a banquet at an authentic Renaissance palace!

flexible.wysiwyg:
A great extra virgin olive oil is not only an absolute delicacy, it is also something that embodies history, tradition, culture, landscape, nature, biodiversity… It’s a way of life, which has characterized the Mediterranean world for millennia, and nowadays, is a gastronomic reference around the world.

The province of Jaén, in the heart of Andalusia, is the hub of the olive growing sector at an international level. With more than 60 million olive trees, this region generates 20% of the world’s production of olive oil. Alongside one of the greatest experts in ACEITE DE OLIVA (olive oil) in Spain, we will see first-hand a day in the life of one of the top family-owned olive oil producers.

This particular olive grove, located on a 1,500-hectare estate, has belonged to the family since 1780. It is unique in its form of biodynamic agriculture that it adheres to, using the latest technology in the production and conservation of its oils. We will visit a modern olive oil mill, where the different types of olive oil are produced, and if we coincide with the harvesting season, we can even pick the olives by hand and participate in the extraction of their oil.

 

We can finish with a visit to the family residence, a Renaissance palace that accommodated King Charles V during his travels in Jaén and which has been listed as a national monument since 1931. We will discover its historical rooms and halls which are normally closed to the public, and we will be able to enjoy a lunch or dinner in the stately dining room. Let’s not forget either that all this is located in an area of enormous natural biodiversity and beauty, making it an ideal place for observing dozens of bird species.

The olive tree is surely the richest gift of Heaven

Thomas Jefferson, politician (1743-1826)

fields.intro: Doñana National Park is one of Europe’s largest wetlands. As a key crossroads for migratory bird routes between Africa and Europe it makes for one of the best places for birdwatching on the continent.
fields.intro_mobile: Doñana National Park is one of Europe’s largest wetlands. As a key crossroads for migratory bird routes between Africa and Europe it makes for one of the best places for birdwatching on the continent.

flexible.wysiwyg:
Doñana is one of the most important nature reserves in Europe and the stunning natural beauty of the wetlands changes with each season. The land is named after Ana (‘Doña Ana’) de Silva y Mendoza, the wife of the seventh Duke of Medina-Sidonia and former owner of the area.

It is located in Andalucía, and straddles the provinces of Huelva, Seville and Cádiz, covering an area of 543 km2 (over 209 sq miles).  It sits between the mouths of the rivers Guadalquivir and Tinto where they flow into the Atlantic Ocean.

It has a biodiversity that is unique in Europe, in just one day you can see several ecosystems: marshlands, lagoons, pine groves, aloe vera, shifting sand dunes, cliffs and over 18 miles of unspoiled white beaches.

Thanks to its strategic location between  Europe and Africa and its proximity to the Strait of Gibraltar, Doñana is a transit point for thousands of European and African birds, with many species of migratory waterfowl spending the winter here. It also provides a habitat for more than 200 bird species whose existence is under threat.  In the spring the place hosts Mediterranean and African species such as the spoonbill and the greater flamenco. Doñana is a must for birdwatching in Spain.

Declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1994, it’s also a safe haven for endangered species such as the Spanish imperial eagle and the Iberian Lynx.

In fact, this place should be on the bucket list of anyone who loves nature and wildlife. A UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1994, Doñana is also a safe haven for endangered species such as the Spanish imperial eagle and the Iberian Lynx. Get to observe the Lynx in the wild or simply delight in the amazing photo opportunities; indulge your botanic whims or enjoy the stunning scenery on a hike. Only 45 minutes from Seville, Spain Collection can organise a trip to this spectacular reserve in the company of a biologist and expert guide. If the weather permits, we can organise a picnic lunch for you, if not enjoy a delicious typical Andalusian lunch at a private home in the nearby village of Rocío.

 

(*)A curious fact: In 1797 Francisco de Goya stayed in the palace as a guest of his patrons, the 15th Duke of Medina-Sidonia and his wife, the 13th Duchess of Alba. Here Goya apparently painted his famous portraits, La Maja Vestida ‘The Clothed Maja’) and La Maja Desnuda (‘The Naked Maja’), rumored to portray the duchess.

 

Nature does not hurry, yet everything is accomplished.

— Lao Tzu, Philosopher, 6th century bc.

fields.intro_mobile: Visiting the mountains of 'Sierra de Grazalema' is like stepping back in time, to the last Ice Age. The 'PINSAPO' (Spanish fir) is like a living fossil, a miracle we have to protect. Our past is our future.

flexible.wysiwyg:
One of the treasures you can find in the province of Cádiz (Andalucía) is the Abies Pinsapo (Spanish Fir) forest, which is found in the mountains of ‘Sierra de Grazalema’, the highest point in Cádiz, and classified as a Biosphere Reserve by UNESCO since 1984.

It is the rainiest spot in the whole of Spain (even more than in the north of the country), with an average annual rainfall of 2,200mm. This is the reason why this tree has been able to thrive here.

The sierra’s deep canyons and glorious green landscapes are impressive. In the winter, the mountains are covered in snow, even though this is one of the warmest regions in the country.

The Spanish Fir which survived the last Ice Age. The tree has a certain elegance to it, typically growing to a height of about 25 meters and is conical in shape. Its growth is dense and is a rich green in colour, although occasionally some have a blue colouration to them. This gorgeous tree, considered the Andalusian National tree, can only be found here, in southern Spain and northern Morocco.

The sierra is a botanical jewel and has its own unique ecosystem. In the last Ice Age, these kinds of forests covered much of the southern Mediterranean region, today it has been reduced to just one hundred hectares. Important conservation efforts now mean that some lost ground is gradually being recovered. Access to the area is strictly controlled and only a limited number of people are allowed in every day. Spain Collection gives you the unique opportunity to visit this hidden green gem, in the company of a specialized forest guide who will explain why this place is so special. This fascinating activity is suitable both for adults and children.

 

Study nature, love nature, stay close to nature. It will never fail you.

— Frank Lloyd Wright, Architect (1867-1959) —

fields.intro: The world of Flamenco is so rich that it not only encompasses dancing, music and art, but it also has a huge influence on Spanish fashion. Experience for yourself how a flamenco dress is not simply something you ‘wear’, it is about posture, the way you move and the way you feel.
fields.intro_mobile: The world of Flamenco is so rich that it not only encompasses dancing, music and art, but it also has a huge influence on Spanish fashion. Experience for yourself how a flamenco dress is not simply something you ‘wear’, it is about posture, the way you move and the way you feel.

flexible.wysiwyg:
Andalusia conjures up the most iconic images and most representative traditions of Spain, such as bullfighting, flamenco and the Easter processions. Each and every tradition is highly stylised. The world of bullfighting has the ‘traje de luces’ worn by the bullfighters, which includes the cape, bolero jacket, waistcoat, and knee-length, skin-tight trousers. The art of flamenco has the beautiful figure-hugging dresses with their frills and ruffles, full of embroidery worn with manila shawls, fans and hair combs. And then we have the tradition of the Holy Week, with the black mantillas and dresses for the women, and the navy-blue suits for the men.

Spain Collection invites you to experience first-hand the beauty, style and sophistication of Flamenco fashion. In the company of a fashion expert you will visit one of the most important ateliers specialized in this most iconic style of dressing. See how the best designers develop their ideas and projects, and learn about the art of flecking, one of the most colorful and complex textile crafts which forms the basis of the well-known manila shawls. Feel the elegance of the handcrafted embroidery on tulle of the Spanish mantillas and admire the different brocade patterns with which the beautiful jackets of the TORERO (bullfighters) are made.

The experience is completed with a private catwalk show in which these beautiful pieces will be shown, and you will have the opportunity to purchase any pieces that catch your eye. A fascinating journey which fully immerses you into this facet of Spanish tradition.

An extract of fire and venom; this is Flamenco

— Antonio Gades, Flamenco dancer (1936-2004) —

fields.intro: The catwalk is where fashion comes alive. Be a model for a day and lose yourself in the backstage world of nerves and frenetic preparations before stepping out into the spotlights and onto the catwalk.

flexible.wysiwyg:
Can you imagine strutting down a catwalk at a real fashion show? Fancy a day in the shoes of a model, from the backstage prep to the walk down the runway, showing off the creations of the country’s best designers and being admired head-to-toe by the audience? Spain Collection offers you a unique experience to feel like a top model for a day.

 

The SIMOF, the International Flamenco Fashion Show, is considered by its own merit the biggest and best example of a flamenco catwalk in the world. Every year, at the beginning of February, more than 80 flamenco fashion brands come together in Seville, showing more than 1,700 flamenco dresses from prestigious designers such as Lina, Pilar Vera, Cristo Báñez and Lourdes Montes. You will have the opportunity to walk the runway in creations by the most renowned designers in the business. You will experience the rehearsals and preparations prior to the official catwalk: the fittings, make-up, hairdressing, and backstage atmosphere…

However, if you prefer to be part of the PUBLICO (audience), you can do that too, accompanied by a fashion expert or perhaps a celebrity from the world of fashion. Attend this international event, with drinks in the ‘kissing area’ and posing for photographers at the ‘photocall’. A fabulous experience that we are sure you will never forget.

Give a girl the right kind of shoes and she will rule the world

— Marilyn Monroe, actress and model. (1926-1962) —

fields.intro: The Arab baths are one of  the best places to relax in Granada. Let the waters take the weight of the world off your shoulders and let the soothing music wash over you.

flexible.wysiwyg:
Granada, one of the most magical places in Spain, used to be an important trading centre between North Africa and Europe. Today it is one of the most important places in Spain for Spanish-Islamic architecture, art, culture and traditions.

The stunning Alhambra sits at the top of many visitors’ “must do” lists but many don’t realise that the city is also home to some of the oldest hammams in the country. For centuries locals have frequented the hammams here to relax.

Hammams reduce stress, their waters inducing a deep sense of relaxation as well as helping to improve the body’s blood circulation.

Pamper yourself! Enjoy the zen-like oasis with its candle-lit walkways and the gentle sound of lapping waters.

 In the waters of Granada, only the sighs row

— Federico García Lorca. Writer.(1898-1936) —

destinations.description: Whether you’re looking for the most amazing food, breath-taking scenery or ground-breaking architecture, northern Spain shatters any stereotype of our country.

fields.intro: La Rioja is synonymous with the production of wine, and is deservedly famed for its world-class wines. Savor the essence of the terroir, where the passion for the grape is everywhere you turn.

flexible.wysiwyg:
‘The land of wine’, La Rioja is undoubtedly one of those places where vineyards and the land are inextricably linked to its people and traditions. With Spain Collection enjoy private visits of centuries-old wine cellars or learn about some of the most innovative architectural creations directly from the professional architects themselves who will reveal the secrets of the most avant-garde wine facilities.

Likewise, enjoy an introduction to the world of wine with the winemakers who will open the doors to their homes and allow us to sample wines they have produced and which have been awarded 100 points in the famous Robert Parker guide. In the company of its patrons you will be taken round one of the best wine museums in the world, with pieces from ancient Egypt, original Roman mosaics, and paintings by Miró or Juan Gris waiting to surprise you amongst the BARRICAS (barrels).

La Rioja also boasts a fantastic gastronomy built upon a fine culinary tradition with exceptional local produce, and nowadays complemented by internationally-recognised chefs such as Francis Paniego or the Echapresto brothers. If you have a ‘sweet tooth’ our private workshops with a local award-winning pastry chef are a must!  Learn about the secrets of chocolate and wine through his unique creations and his philosophy of ‘bean-to-bar’ sustainability.

Accept what life offers you and try to drink from every cup. All wines should be tasted; some should only be sipped, but with others, drink the whole bottle

― Paulo Coelho. Writer. born 1947 ―

fields.intro: Who doesn’t love chocolate? This is your chance to make your ‘sweetest’ dreams come true!

flexible.wysiwyg:
La Rioja has many secrets to discover, and probably one you would least expect is our chocolate indulgence experience. This activity is ideal for families with kids, and let’s be honest, for anyone with a sweet tooth!

Discover the secrets of this centuries-old confection with our award-winning pastry chef. Following our master’s sustainable ‘bean-to-bar’ philosophy, we will return to the origins of chocolate and find out about its cultivation whilst making our own creations.

We will learn how to bake and cook the coolest chocolate cakes, as well as challenge ourselves with the creative proposals of our chef ranging from chocolate rose petals to Rioja wine TRUFAS (truffles).

Nothing is as alluring as a piece of chocolate you can’t have…

— Nina Sandmann. Writer, born 1967 —

fields.intro: Is there any kind of love greater than the love of food? We bet there isn’t, and guess what? We want to show you. Come and join us!

flexible.wysiwyg: The founders of Spain Collection are Basque, and it is in the Basque Country that we have not only our headquarters, but also our heart. And when it comes to food, we Basques know what we’re talking about better than anyone else! That’s why you should trust us to introduce you to San Sebastian, a gourmet destination par excellence, with the world record of Michelin stars per square meter. Not only will we open the doors to some of the greatest restaurants featured in the Michelin guide, but we will also take you to the restaurant with the best wine cellar in the world, where you can dine surrounded by one of the most incredible collections of wine you’ll ever see, including wines of which only a few BOTELLAS (bottles) remain in the world. This is an experience fit for a king, literally!

And then we have the pintxos.  You can either venture out on your own or go with one of our local food guides. Make your way round our favourite bars and try our hand-picked specialty at each, from the more traditional bite-sized snack to the most cutting-edge pintxo.

Ask not what you can do for your country. Ask what’s for lunch

— Orson Welles – Actor, Director and Producer (1915-1985) —

fields.intro: This is possibly the most famous Spanish ‘fiesta’ of them all, and arguably the one we should all try to experience first-hand at some point in our lives!  Year after year thousands of people from all over the world flock here, seduced by this truly unique event

flexible.wysiwyg: The moment that everybody holds their breath for is the ‘encierros’. The ‘encierro’ is literally the running of the bulls from their stables to the city’s bullring, via the city centre of Pamplona. The run starts at 8am and covers just over 800 meters, not a huge distance perhaps but it’s big on adrenaline! With Spain Collection enjoy this legendary spectacle from the balcony of a private house on one the streets down which the bulls and ‘mozos’ (young men who run in front of the bulls) run.

But you will also be able to experience the ‘fiesta’ in many other ways such as a typical breakfast of hot chocolate with ‘churros’ (finger-like doughnuts for dipping into the chocolate), or a walk round the city with a member of a local ‘peña’. The Peñas are local associations, often groups of friends, that exist in every city, town and village of Spain. Their participation in local festivities is what packs these fiestas full of character, colour, noise and atmosphere. He will take us to all the ‘must-know’ places and will talk to us about the figure of Hemingway, whose time in Spain has become a narrative in which much myth has been interwoven into the facts.

And if you are a bullfighting fan, remember that Pamplona holds some of the biggest events on the bullfighting calendar. Its PLAZA (bullring) is the third largest in the world, after Mexico City and Madrid. Let us take you to a bullfight –  we will get you the best seats and you will learn about the rituals, drama and passion behind this iconic spectacle.

Courage is grace under pressure

― Ernst Hemingway. Writer. 1899-1961 ―

fields.intro: The passion for wine in La Rioja is entrenched in the region’s customs and traditions. The craftsmanship behind barrel making and making of wineskins are essential to understanding the way of life of the people here.
fields.intro_mobile: The passion for wine in La Rioja is entrenched in the region’s customs and traditions. The craftsmanship behind barrel making and making of wineskins are essential to understanding the way of life of the people here.

flexible.wysiwyg:
There is no doubt the name Rioja will evoke rolling landscapes of valleys and vineyards, and of course the aroma of one of the most renowned wines in the world. This time, rather than showing you how and where wine is made, we want you to immerse yourself in some of the very local traditions of this beautiful land and its people.

The oak barrels and the craftsmanship behind them are an essential part of the wine-making tradition. There aren’t many companies that still make their own barrels in the old fashion way. Let us take you to our master ‘tonelero’ and prepare to be mesmerized by a play of fire, iron and meticulous craftsmanship. See how the wooden barrel’s staves are toasted according to the vintner’s own personal taste. His instructions impact the bouquet of the wine he then produces.

But even for the average strong ‘Riojanos’, a 225 liter barrel is still quite heavy to carry to the middle of the vineyards for a picnic, so they invented the wineskin or ‘bota’ to call it by its Spanish name. There are only a handful of artisans who still master the technique of hand making these traditional wineskins, and our friend Felix is one of them. He learnt it from his father and he from his father before him. This patience-testing job starts with the tanning of animal skins and then there’s the process of sewing it together and the meticulous treatment to have it waterproofed, well actually ‘wineproofed’. Under our master’s watchful eye, we will have the chance to try and make our own wineskins.

Once finished, the tricky part will be to learn how to drink from them in the traditional way, pouring the wine straight from the wineskins’ mouthpiece without spilling it all over the place. Then we’ll be able to blend in with the locals at the next lamb-chop grilling party!

Age appears best in four things: Old wood to burn, old wine to drink, old friends to trust and old authors to read

– Francis Bacon. Philosopher (1561-1626) –

fields.intro: There are certain places where time seems to have stood still, where the traveler finds the purpose of his journey,and places blessed by magic.

flexible.wysiwyg:
Experience the world of wine beyond the usual visit to a winery. The owners of this small vineyard near the historic town of Laguardia, in the Rioja Alavesa wine region, have chosen to follow the path of organic farming, without giving up on aspirations to top the Parker guide. The path of organic vine cultivation is very rare in La Rioja and is the choice of but a brave few. This is very much an exclusive vineyard, where you will find a very authentic viticulture experience.

Depending on the time of year, and in the company of the owner of the estate, we can participate in different tasks around the vineyard such as: pruning, de-stalking (cutting off the non-fertile green shoots), thinning (removing part of the clusters to improve the quality of the rest of the vine), harvesting, treading grapes, etc. Every moment of the year is different, and our visit here will be dictated by needs of the land at that time.

We can also organise a relaxing massage for you amongst the vines, whilst for the little ones, we can organize a treasure hunt which explains the fascinating history of the place to them, such as the ‘guardaviñas’, circular stone huts – unique to La Rioja – which were used by the farmers as shelters and as a place to store their tools.

Saving the best till last – how about a barbecue in the vineyard: vine-roasted suckling lamb, served with locally-grown vegetables and typical sausages. All prepared by our hosts.

What though youth gave love and roses, Age still leaves us friends and wine

— Thomas Moore – Poet, (1779-1852) —

fields.intro: Castile, literally the land of castles, is the very heart of central Spain. It oozes medieval history with castles and fortresses set against vast natural landscapes which have inspired poets and travelers for centuries.

flexible.wysiwyg:
The Ribera del Duero is the D.O. (appellation) which has brought the most international prestige to Spanish wines with world-renowned references such as Pesquera or Vega Sicilia. Explore the land and learn from Spain Collection about the work of visionaries, such as Don Alejandro Fernández, who knew that some of the best VINOS (wines) in the world could be produced from a hard, arid land, with soils that had previously been used to grow crops such as cereals and beets.

Enjoy a private visit or have one of our renowned chefs prepare some of their culinary wonders at the vineyards. This wine region, located in the heart of Castile, means we can combine visiting medieval castles dating back to the 11th century with wine tastings and private dinners in their courtyards!

 

I would love to be made of wine so I could drink myself

— Federico García Lorca, Poet (1898-1936) —

fields.intro: R+D is key in every sector, and it is no different in the wine industry. The Basque Country, as a prominent gourmet & wine destination, was the location selected for this unique project designed to make use of the tides in the ageing process of wine.

flexible.wysiwyg:
The beautiful Plentzia bay, on the Basque coast, hides an incredible secret: a winery that uses the coastal tides to age the wine. Accompanied by the owner of the winery, we will make our way to the ‘cellars’ by boat and divers will retrieve cages loaded with bottles from the sea for a wine-tasting like no other!

Afterwards we will visit the private hillside vineyard, and with spectacular views of the sea, we will enjoy an outdoor lunch.

For those who really want to know more about the process we can organise a visit to the estate’s warehouse facility (not open to the public), and with the owner of the winery we can try wines ‘before’ and ‘after’ being submerged in the depths of the sea.

My soul is full of longing for the secret of the sea, and the heart of the great ocean sends a thrilling pulse through me

— Henry Wadsworth Longfellow -American Poet (1801-1882) —

experiences.name: Sports
experiences.description: Do you enjoy sports from an armchair or do you prefer to be out in the thick of it?

destinations.name: Euskadi & Northern Spain
destinations.description: Whether you’re looking for the most amazing food, breath-taking scenery or ground-breaking architecture, northern Spain shatters any stereotype of our country.

fields.intro: Most people have heard about the fiercely competitive Oxford vs Cambridge boat race; but few know that at around the same time, in 1850, the Basques had their own particular boat race too.

flexible.wysiwyg:
‘Estropada’ means regatta in Basque. This sport, like all the other traditional Basque sports, is connected to our history, work and our ancestors’ daily lives. The Basques used to be whaling people and they used a type of rowing boat called a ‘trainera’ to hunt the whales. Today these boats are used in a competition that attracts thousands of people, every September, to watch the spectacle of ‘Bandera de La Concha’, in San Sebastian.

The ‘trainera’ row-boat regattas are a sport that combines huge physical effort, coordination, teamwork, and a lot of dedication. In spite of the sport’s popularity, rowers do not usually achieve individual fame: big egos have no place in the boats, there is only room for hard work and team spirit. That is what makes this activity so special. Whilst we discover a fascinating part of our history and traditions from times gone by, we will also try to transmit what, for Spain Collection, is the very essence of travel: to learn and incorporate into our way of being, experiences that make us better people. You will have the time of your lives!

We want to share this unique experience with you and make you feel like whalers for a day. Our fierce, strong rowers will help you in this feat, rowing as one, exceeding our expectations and pushing our limits. The activity takes place in the old port of San Sebastian, although there are other possible locations on the Basque coast. We will start with a pep talk from the skipper. He will explain the basics of the sport, what it consists of, the rules, and the traditions. Depending on the number of people, we will form two teams that will compete against each other, or a single team that will compete against itself. Be prepared, because the boats have to be carried into the water on the shoulders of the team, in this case, you with your team-mates for the day. This is a sport for strong boys and girls. Our skipper will set the pace and little by little we will learn to row in unison. Eventually, we will manoeuvre into the center of the bay for the start of the race. There will be shouting and sweating, but above all adrenaline. This we can promise you.

 

The winners will receive a champion’s ‘txapela’ (Basque beret). The word for ‘champion’ in Basque is ‘txapelduna’, or for a more literal translation, ‘the one who wears the txapela’. And then when you sit down at the table to devour a delicious Donostian-style sea bream, you will know that all of you have really earned it!

 

For the children and those preferring to stay on dry land but who want to know more about the history of the Basques and the sea, we can take you to see how historical replicas of 16th century whaling boats are built today, using the same techniques, materials and tools from all those centuries ago.

 

A whale ship was my Yale college and my Harvard

– Herman Melville, Novelist, 1819, 1891 –

fields.intro: The Basque Country is an internationally recognized surfers’ paradise, with great destinations for those dreamers who travel in search of the best waves in camper vans covered in sand and salt.

flexible.wysiwyg:
Mundaka, about 40 minutes by car from Bilbao, is a small coastal town of unquestionable charm, but it is also utopia by the sea: it has some of the best waves in Europe, barrels of up to 4 meters high and 400 meters long.  This is why it also has its own surfing championship and has been part of the world circuit on nine occasions. Kelly Slater, Mark Occhilupo and Bobby Martínez have all seen glory in Mundaka.

A resident from the village will open his home to us. A property with some of the best views of the Atlantic which laps the shore of Mundaka. We’ll get to hear the history of the town first-hand from our host whilst we prepare ourselves for this first foray into the world of surfing with a local surfer. We have all the material for you to enjoy this experience to the fullest: wetsuits, boards, booties… Making our way down to the beach by a private path, the first step in this adventure will be on the sand where we get to understand our boards and the basic moves. We will then head into the sea, with its famous barrel wave that forms an integral part of this unique landscape, a landscape that will sometimes make us want to simply sit on our boards to let it all sink in.

If stand up paddle surf is more your thing, then you’re in the right place because the route between marshes and sand is simply stunning.

Finally, we will enjoy a well-deserved, delicious aperitif prepared with local gourmet products either on the beach or on the private terrace of our host’s villa.

It’s like the mafia. Once you’re in – you’re in. There’s no getting out

– Kelly Slater – American Surfer, born 1972 –

fields.intro: Bilbao is a small, big city that surprises many with its cosmopolitan character and audacious architecture. Almost all the great architects of our time have left their mark on the city, creating an urban model that serves as an example for the architecture of the third millennium.

flexible.wysiwyg:
The Guggenheim Museum Bilbao, designed by Canadian architect Frank O Gehry, has become a temple of contemporary art.  This fabulous space houses major touring exhibitions that can be difficult to find in other museums around the world as well as a very important permanent collection where all the great artists of today are represented together with large format works such as ‘The matter of time’ by Richard Serra, ‘Maman’ by Louise Bourgeois or ‘Tulips’ by Jeff Koons. The museum also has a large collection of masterpieces from the 20th century by Rothko, Liechtenstein, Kiefer, Warhol, Basquiat and a long etcetera.

Our company, founded in Bilbao, has a strong link with this museum, since it was the catalyst behind its creation, back in 1998. Therefore, this experience is, in a way, much more ‘Spain Collection’ than any other. One of our art experts will guide you through the halls of the museum, explain the history of the building, as well bring to life the permanent and temporary collections that are on show at that time.

We will also take you on an exclusive tour of the most impressive private art gallery in Bilbao, where you will feel the pulse and drive of the artistic life of this city. Not only will we get to explore the exhibition spaces, but also its ‘backstage’, where many of the works belonging to the gallery are preserved and stored. We will end our visit, amongst some fabulous works of art, with a glass of cava.

Art does not reproduce what is visible. It makes it visible

– Paul Klee – Artist, (1879-1940) –

1301.title: Eduardo Chillida: The Legacy Of a Great Artist

experiences.name: Culture
experiences.description: Spain and Portugal combined have more UNESCO World Heritage Sites than any other place in the world.

destinations.name: Euskadi & Northern Spain
destinations.description: Whether you’re looking for the most amazing food, breath-taking scenery or ground-breaking architecture, northern Spain shatters any stereotype of our country.

fields.intro: If there is any Basque in our recent history that deserves to be honored, it has to be Eduardo Chillida: he is, without wishing to offend Richard Serra, the greatest sculptor of the second half of the 20th century.

flexible.wysiwyg:
This internationally renowned Basque artist created works of art that today can be found all over the world: Tokyo, Berlin, Bonn, Barcelona, Madrid, Basel, Munich, Düsseldorf, Seville, Gijón, Houston, Washington, Dallas, Helsinki…. It’s his large-format sculptural work in Corten steel that brought him international recognition. Yet it’s in his engravings, in his drawings of hands, in his smaller works made in alabaster, where we find the emotion and delicacy of this immense creator. And in Euskadi, his birthplace, examples of his legacy abound.

A direct descendant of the artist will show and guide us, behind closed doors, through the life and work of Eduardo Chillida in the museum created by the family, Chillida Leku. The visit will culminate with a private aperitif amongst the sculptor’s impressive works of art.

For die-hard fans, we can complement the activity with a visit to Legazpia, where Chillida forged – and yes, this is the right word for it – as many of his large format works came to life at a local steel mill.

Art is connected to the undone, to what has not been created yet. It is something outside yourself, something ahead of you, and you must seek it

– Eduardo Chillida – Sculptor (1924-2002) –

experiences.name: Religious Heritage
experiences.description: The Knights Templar, the Jesuits, Islam, the Sephardic legacy, the history of the Moors, none of these can be studied or better understood without setting foot in Spain or Portugal.

destinations.name: Euskadi & Northern Spain
destinations.description: Whether you’re looking for the most amazing food, breath-taking scenery or ground-breaking architecture, northern Spain shatters any stereotype of our country.

fields.intro: For many, the creation of Europe began centuries ago thanks to El Camino de Santiago when pilgrims from across the continent journeyed hundreds if not thousands of miles thus becoming the first international tourists.

flexible.wysiwyg:
Very few or perhaps no-one could have imagined that a French pilgrim, who may or may not have been a monk, known by the name Aymeric Picaud, would end up leading the ‘way’ to Santiago de Compostela for millions of pilgrims. In around 1140 he wrote the ‘Pilgrim Guide to Santiago de Compostela’, which is included in the 5th book of the ‘Codex Calixtus’, also called ‘Liber Sancti Jacobi’.  It is considered one of the first travel guide books ever written.

For over 1,000 years, pilgrims have followed the stars guiding their weary feet to the tomb of one of Jesus’ most important disciples, one of the twelve apostles, Saint James the Greater. Their footprints left a network of new pathways, villages and buildings, such as hostels for pilgrims (ALBERGUES), small sanctuaries and churches as well as some of the most stunning cathedrals in Europe. They also brought with them fables and tales, stories about redemption and indulgences, about sin and virtue, and about the mundane and divine aspects of life.

 

El Camino, is without a doubt the most famous walking pilgrimage in the world and while there was the ‘Primitive’ route back in the 9th Century, which King Alfonso II of Asturias took from Oviedo to Compostela, it was in the 12th century when the ‘French Way’ became the one known as ‘el Camino de Santiago’.

El Camino, is without a doubt the most famous walking pilgrimage in the world and while there was the ‘Primitive’ route back in the 9th Century, which King Alfonso II of Asturias took from Oviedo to Compostela, it was in the 12th century when the ‘French Way’ became the one known as ‘el Camino de Santiago’.

In the 20th century, Father Elías Valiña (1929-1989), a former parish priest from Santa María del Cebreiro in Galicia, picked up the baton from Aymeric Picaud and started to assist modern pilgrims and help them make their way to Compostela by modernizing the network of public ALBERGUES and improving the signage along the route with the iconic yellow arrows and scallop shells which bring so much relief to lost pilgrims.

PEREGRINO, whether you chose the classic French way, the more demanding Primitive Camino or the less traveled scenic Coastal Portuguese Camino, let our experts assist you as you are about to embark in a spiritual journey that many others have endured and enjoyed before you.

And remember that if you do not find El Camino, El Camino will always find you!

Santiago has become the joy of people from across the world. Because of this, those who arrive in sadness return joyfully…

– Codex Calixtinus (12th century book) –

1324.title: The Royal Spas of Northern Spain

experiences.name: Body & Soul
experiences.description: Life can get hectic sometimes, so treat yourself with Spain's spas and other plans to wind down like yoga and mindfulness healing.

destinations.name: Euskadi & Northern Spain
destinations.description: Whether you’re looking for the most amazing food, breath-taking scenery or ground-breaking architecture, northern Spain shatters any stereotype of our country.

fields.intro: Sometimes it seems that going to the beach and bathing in the sea is something absolutely normal and something we’ve always done, but it is actually a relatively recent trend.

flexible.wysiwyg:
In Spain there are certain cities, today important tourist destinations, which flourished thanks to the influence of the royal family and the European nobility at the end of the 19th century. These coastal towns went from being little more than fishing villages to spa towns with sumptuous palaces, and hotels built to house these distinguished visitors, who demanded all kinds of luxury and comforts.

In this context, cities like Santander and San Sebastian in northern Spain, or Biarritz in southern France, became home to the top tier of European royalty and aristocracy. Galicia also became known for its spas such as La Toja and Mondaríz. Queen María Cristina, regent of Spain after the death of King Alfonso XII, their son King Alfonso XIII, and his wife Queen Victoria Eugenia, are some of the great historical figures who defined this era and who, with their presence, transformed these cities.

That is why when we propose experiencing Spain’s best Thalasso spa, the La Perla spa in San Sebastian, we are talking about much more than a circuit of thermal waters: it is like taking a dip in the history of San Sebastian. The emblematic Hotel Maria Cristina, the Victoria Eugenia Theater, and all the aristocratic inheritance of this city came into being thanks to the city’s waters. La Perla, from its unique location on the beach of La Concha with views of the bay, is symbolic of this imperial past, and the luxuries reserved for royal families, all of which can now be enjoyed by guests of Spain Collection. And don’t forget to finish your visit with a swim in the waters of La Concha bay: you’ll feel as good as new!

The cure for everything is always salt water: sweat, tears or the sea

– Karen Blixen (also known as Isak Dinesen) – Author (1885-1962) –

flexible.wysiwyg:
If you have a gourmand soul and thought watching celebrities cook was fun, this is definitely for you! Learn about local gastronomy and how to prepare it in the format of the popular TV show (Master Chef). We can organize a complete experience, from the vegetable garden to the kitchen, under the watchful eye of our culinary experts. You will get to prepare traditional Spanish dishes as well as having the opportunity to venture into the world of the avant-garde cuisine of our Michelin-starred chefs.

Put your skills to the test at some of the venues used for the filming of the series such as El Casino in Madrid or a 5 star wine-hotel in Castile where Christopher Columbus spent the night as he prepared to embark in search of the new world. This is an enormously fun experience suitable for the whole family where you will also be able to meet some of the famous chefs who have participated in the program as either judges or participants!

Don your apron and get ready to have a great time with this exclusive Spain Collection experience!

Cooking is about passion, so it may look slightly temperamental in a way that it’s too assertive to the naked eye

– Gordon Ramsay. Chef and TV star. Born 1966 –

fields.intro: If Spanish cuisine is an exceptional experience in itself, enjoying it at a Michelin-star restaurant is something that will live on in your memory forever.

flexible.wysiwyg: In 2020 we have a total of 24 Michelin star restaurants in Madrid. If generally enjoying a meal means tasty food and wine, good presentation on the plate, in a nice location and great service, having a so-called ‘Michelin experience’ elevates the cuisine to a whole new level. The question of going to a Michelin star restaurant is not only about wanting an outstanding food experience. It is also about learning how Michelin star chefs create their exceptional PLATOS (dishes) and celebrate their incredible creations in front of their clients.

The wide variety of Michelin restaurants (in terms of quantity and gastronomic diversity) we have in Madrid means it’s possible to enjoy the creations of a whole range of chefs each with their own style. Spain Collection has prepared for you the very best selection of Michelin restaurants where you can learn the secrets of olive oil at a private atelier (and even create your olive oil foam!), have a one-on-one experience with a Michelin-starred chef ( even having a private class) or sample cocktails or sherries guided by an expert sommelier while you enjoy your food and wait in anticipation for the next course to be served.

Food is my means of expression, of seeing life and living it

– Jesús Sánchez, 3 Michelin star-chef.Born 1964 –

experiences.name: Food & Wine
experiences.description: You will visit the best restaurants in the city and you can try their most traditional dishes

destinations.name: Madrid
destinations.description: Madrid, the heart of Spain. Its vast history, aristocratic character, cultural diversity and cosmopolitan soul permeate the psyche of the “Madrileños” on the streets...

fields.intro: Don’t miss this opportunity to discover the history, authenticity and cuisine of Madrid! The perfect way to devour this city… in every sense of the word.

flexible.wysiwyg:
When we talk about Spanish cuisine, one of the first words that comes to most minds is ‘TAPAS’. This dish, actually more of a snack to accompany a drink, is closely linked to the city of Madrid with its origins dating back to the 13th century, when King Alfonso X the Wise ordered that the taverns and inns of Castile serve alcoholic beverages with a small portion of food to avoid people getting drunk. Another theory, however, suggests that the glass of wine or beer was covered with a slice of bread to prevent dust and flies from getting into the drink, thus giving rise to the word ‘tapa’, the Spanish word for cover or lid.

Be that as it may, tapas have evolved since those times and are one of the most representative elements of Spanish cuisine. In the Basque Country we have pintxos, which have elevated this appetizer to the category of gourmet dish; in Andalusia, the tapas are generous in size and often they are included in the price of the drink; whilst in Madrid they have the same traditional character as the taverns, bars and inns that have been serving them for centuries.

Spain Collection offers a selection of the best places to ‘tapear’, not only because of the quality of their products, but also because of the importance that these places have in the history of Madrid. Imagine eating the same croquettes that so captivated U2’s Bono? Or trying some prawns at the bar where Andy Warhol once leaned on his elbow? Or how about daring to eat the chicken dish, ‘gallina en pepitoria’, at the tavern that witnessed the assassination attempt on King Alfonso XIII? Madrid also has its own very traditional cuisine, so you can try the best Madrid stew in 19th century taverns, or Michelin-starred tripe or, for those that are really hungry, enjoy suckling lamb prepared in a wood-fired oven at the oldest inn in Madrid.

The stomach rules the mind

– Spanish proverb –

experiences.name: Culture
experiences.description: Spain and Portugal combined have more UNESCO World Heritage Sites than any other place in the world.

destinations.name: Madrid
destinations.description: Madrid, the heart of Spain. Its vast history, aristocratic character, cultural diversity and cosmopolitan soul permeate the psyche of the “Madrileños” on the streets...

fields.intro: Behind the door of every building in Madrid you will find insights on the history and culture of this city, but at Palacio Liria you will discover a legacy on such a scale that it will leave you speechless.

flexible.wysiwyg:
Madrid is a city renowned for its great cultural wealth. Capital of Spain since 1562, the Royal Court’s influence on the city is still very present in its streets, squares and parks, with urban buildings that house palaces and mansions with elegant facades, fascinating interiors and historic art collections.

 

Liria Palace is an absolute highlight. It dates back to the end of the 18th century and has been the official residence of the House of Alba since 1802. This stately home houses this noble family’s art collection and an historical archive, making it one of the PALACIOS (palaces) with the greatest artistic and historical relevance in Madrid.

Visit this unique palace with private access to the chapel, the music room, and spectacular gardens. Accompanied by a guide specialising in art history you will also discover the palace library, which houses many historical treasures, such as the only privately-held collection of letters from Christopher Columbus in existence, the last will of King Fernando ‘The Catholic’ and a first edition of ‘Don Quixote’ in Madrid from 1605.

The visit can be wrapped with a private dinner in one of the palace’s rooms, prepared by a top local chef.  Enjoy a meal worthy of a noble palate.

 

We are not makers of history. We are made by history

– Martin Luther King Jr., American minister.(1929-1968) –

fields.intro: Cervantes and his Don Quixote are arguably as universal as characters can get. No other fictional character has been so notorious and influential as the man from La Mancha.

flexible.wysiwyg: Don Quixote is a novel of epic proportions and so was the life of the author, Miguel de Cervantes. This unfathomable work of art is also a journey through the life and times of one of the greatest universal writers. The boundaries between creator and character sometimes get blurred as we travel from the university town of Alcala de Henares, birthplace of Cervantes and UNESCO site since 1998, to fight the famous windmills in La Mancha. Accompanied by our literary expert, get ready to dive in and savor the carefully written passages of his books as much as the traditional local meals described in Don Miguel’s novels. From a private MANCHEGO cheese and olive oil tasting at local haciendas (called ‘ventas’) to Michelin-star chefs reimagining Don Quixote’s culinary dreams, join us in this off-the-beaten-path, unique experience somewhere in La Mancha …

He who reads much and walks much, goes far and knows much

– Miguel de Cervantes. Universal writer. (1547-1616) –

1393.title: Flamenco & Madrid - A World Conquering Partnership

experiences.name: Culture
experiences.description: Spain and Portugal combined have more UNESCO World Heritage Sites than any other place in the world.

destinations.name: Madrid
destinations.description: Madrid, the heart of Spain. Its vast history, aristocratic character, cultural diversity and cosmopolitan soul permeate the psyche of the “Madrileños” on the streets...

fields.intro: Flamenco and Madrid: the city that gave this art form a stage from which to enthrall the world.

flexible.wysiwyg: Speaking of Flamenco means speaking of Madrid. The capital of Spain has always been a reference site for all those that want to establish themselves as full artists. Not in vain Madrid has some of the best Flamenco venues you can find in Spain. This artistic expression, declared as Intangible Cultural Heritage by UNESCO in 2010, is present on every corner of Madrid: you will be surprised as you walk around the narrow streets and hidden squares of downtown and you run into a small tavern in which some Flamenco artists are hand-clapping and playing on a CAJÓN (percussion box), while a female dancer starts dancing. Then, following the rhythm of the music and the dance, they begin to sing and, all of a sudden, magic happens!

Spain Collection has selected the best experiences related to this Spanish art form. We will guide you to a cultural foundation where the Flamenco students take their lessons in singing, dancing and playing guitar, box and castanets. Imagine being among these upcoming talents and learn by the best Flamenco professors the first steps of tapping your feet, clapping your hands and moving your body at the rhythm of a Spanish guitar. Or go to what has been awarded as the “Best Tablao Flamenco in the World” and let you mesmerize by a private Flamenco show, just for you, while you enjoy an exquisite Michelin menu.

Flamenco is always sorrow; love is also sorrow. At the end, everything is sorrow and joy.

– Camarón de la Isla, Flamenco singer (1950-1992) –

1401.title: Toledo: The Art of Damascening & Sword-making

experiences.name: Traditions
experiences.description: Some of the traditions in Spain date from thousands of years ago same as some of the customs in Spain. Want to know more?

destinations.name: Madrid
destinations.description: Madrid, the heart of Spain. Its vast history, aristocratic character, cultural diversity and cosmopolitan soul permeate the psyche of the “Madrileños” on the streets...

fields.intro: The impressive buildings and the city’s status as a UNESCO World Heritage Centre are reminders of the important part Toledo has played in Spanish history.

flexible.wysiwyg:
There is art in every nook and cranny of Toledo. A walk through its labyrinth of narrow streets is like entering a universe of artisans who have  been able to preserve the skills and traditions which are part of the essence of a city that has always been a melting pot of cultures.

The sword-making industry of Toledo dates back centuries.  See first-hand what are, arguably, the best handcrafted ESPADAS (swords) in the world, made with the famous ‘Toledan steel’. Participate in a ‘sword-making’ workshop, and experience how this weapon is forged from the heat of fire, through to the final finishing touches and polishing.

Some swords are decorated with the famous ‘damascene’, a technique of goldsmithing that consists of inlaying threads and sheets of gold into steel.  But this technique is not only used for the decoration of weapons, there are also artisan workshops where damascene is incorporated into decorative objects and jewellery. Under the watchful eye of a damascene craftsman, touch and feel how you embed the gold threads, as fine as a strand of hair, into steel. It is a very delicate process for which it is necessary to strike with care using a special hammer.

Tell the Duke of Enghien that we appreciate his words… but this is a Spanish Tercio

– Captain Alatriste, Rocroi Battle, 1643 –

related.post_title: Flamenco & Madrid - A World Conquering Partnership

fields.intro: Talavera is home to communities of artisans who make ceramics for decorative and architectural use. The most significant aspect of their work, however, is that most of their manufacturing, decoration and glazing processes have remained unchanged since the 16th century.

flexible.wysiwyg: The ceramics produced in Talavera de la Reina are part of the UNESCO list of ‘Intangible Cultural Heritage’.  Here we will visit the TALLER (atelier) of one of the most renowned ceramic artists in the country.  This is where work on projects such as the decoration of the restaurant ‘Bazaar Mar’ belonging to award-winning chef, José Andrés was carried out. 6,600 tiles were used!  This also where the mural for the Oran Convention Center in Algeria was designed and created. It is the largest hand-painted ceramic mural in the world.

During your visit you can design and paint your own tile or perhaps create some other decorative piece of ceramic art to take home with you as a souvenir.

Conclude this experience with a visit to the Ceramic Museum of Maestro Ruiz de Luna, a revolutionary ceramics artist in his time, and a friend of other great artists such as Sorolla and Benlliure. He knew how to give this art form the necessary impulse to not only ensure its survival, but to reach heights today when it is now considered one of the most highly respected decorative art techniques in the world.

I thought clay must feel happy in the good potter’s hand

– Jane Fitch,Writer. 1955 –

related.post_title: Toledo: The Art of Damascening & Sword-making

fields.intro: Bullfighting is an iconic tradition in Spain and one of the defining cultural characteristics of this country. Deplored by some and adored by others, bullfighting is a spectacle that straddles the boundaries between art and brutality, passion and controversy.

flexible.wysiwyg: The bull is synonymous with Spain. It is viewed by many as a symbol of Spanish pride. The country itself is often described as a ‘piel de toro’, due to the similarity the Iberian Peninsula bears to the shape of the pelt of a bull. And then we have bullfighting.  This fiesta is very much entrenched in Spanish culture. From writers to presidents, from nobility to the man on the street, bullfighting has attracted people from all walks of life for decades and we’d like to take you on a journey which explains all the ins and outs of this fascinating tradition that leaves no-one indifferent.

We will take you to an atelier to see how the ‘traje de luces’, the traditional clothing worn by bullfighters, is still made by hand with all its intricate embroidery and decoration. We will sample traditional tapas eaten by experts and aficionados alike as they passionately debate which matador made the best LANCES (moves). Celebrity fans have included the likes of Hemmingway and Ava Gardner.  They loved bullfighting and all the intense rituals and ambience surrounding it. Mingle with the vociferous locals, get out your white handkerchief and take a ring-side seat at the plaza with our insiders for an afternoon of excitement and emotion you will never forget.

Bullfighting is the only art in which the artist is in danger of death and in which the degree of brilliance in the performance is left to the fighter’s honor

– Ernest Hemingway. Writer and Journalist (1899 – 1961) –

flexible.wysiwyg: Our destination experts are at your service to make your shopping day an experience beyond prêt à porter. You can never be overdressed or overeducated

– Oscar Wilde, writer (1854-1900) –

fields.intro: Football is an obsession for the Spanish and seeing Real Madrid in action tops the must-see list for any sports aficionado visiting the capital of Spain.

flexible.wysiwyg: If you are one of those people who think football is a religion (or soccer as it is called on the other side of the pond), Madrid is the city for you. The capital of Spain is home to Real Madrid, one of the top teams in the world and named ‘best club of the 20th century’ by FIFA. The club’s museum, and the second most-visited museum in Madrid after El Prado, is located at the Santiago Bernabeu stadium. The exhibition displays the hundreds of trophies, both national and international, won by the club, including the 13 Champion League titles. Real Madrid boasts the most trophies in football in the world.

Sit on the actual team BANQUILLO (bench) or check out the locker room where the stars get ready for action. We can get you access to VIP boxes for a game or arrange a private visit of the training facilities and Real Madrid football academy.  This is where the team’s stars prepare for their matches and where a future ‘Ballon D’or‘ winner or World Cup top striker might just cross your path!

When you put on this shirt, you know that you’ve arrived at the very top. There is no greater honour.

– Sergio Ramos. Real Madrid Captain. Born 1986 –

fields.intro: How to begin to explain the rivalry between these two teams?… There is no other football game in the world as big as 'el Clasico', period.
fields.intro_mobile: How to begin to explain the rivalry between these two teams?… There is no other football game in the world as big as 'el Clasico', period.

flexible.wysiwyg:
If you need clarification on what ‘El Clasico’ means, then you can stop reading this now!

Real Madrid and Barcelona clash at least twice a season, at the homeground of each team – Santiago Bernabéu (Madrid) and the Nou Camp (Barcelona). Getting tickets is beyond difficult but nothing impossible for your Spain Collection Curators if we get the planning right. Hospitality suites are available at both stadiums and we can arrange catering services, staffing, private transfers, etc.

But what if you are a ‘dream big’ kind of person? What if attending El Clasico isn’t enough for you? What if you want your very own private match played just for you? We’re still waiting for that someone who has an epic budget to make it happen, but meanwhile contacts have been secured, phone calls have been made and we are ready: if your wish is to enjoy a Real Madrid vs. Barcelona clash with former players and stars we can deliver. However, if 22 players is a bit much, we can arrange for one or two former players to commentate on any game just for you. Just start dropping names, we’re listening!

Messi or Ronaldo the best player in the world? In the world I would say Ronaldo, Messi is from another planet

– Arda Turán, Football player, Born 1987 –

1478.title: Hunting In The Land Of El Quijote

experiences.name: Sports
experiences.description: Do you enjoy sports from an armchair or do you prefer to be out in the thick of it?

destinations.name: Madrid
destinations.description: Madrid, the heart of Spain. Its vast history, aristocratic character, cultural diversity and cosmopolitan soul permeate the psyche of the “Madrileños” on the streets...

fields.intro: Discover the vast sweeping plateau of Castilla-La Mancha with its windmills, striking red-colored earth, and endless rows of olive trees and grapevines.

flexible.wysiwyg:
In addition to the many villages located in the region of Madrid, known for their beautiful landscapes, the geographical location of Madrid itself, right at the heart of Spain, makes it an ideal starting point from which to explore other parts of the country. Cities like Toledo, Ciudad Real, Segovia, Ávila, Cuenca and Guadalajara are all only one or two hours away and all of them offer spectacular scenery where you can enjoy many outdoor pursuits.

It’s worth highlighting Castilla la Mancha, land of the famous Don Quixote, where the tradition of hunting is one of its main attractions. In Toledo or Ciudad Real, for example, there are several estates specializing in this activity, as well as other outdoor activities such as hiking, 4×4 jeep drives, quad biking routes, clay pigeon shooting, horse riding and hot air ballooning.

Perhaps the most prized, for its beauty and tradition, is the driven partridge shooting. We can either participate from the hunters’ position, for those with experience in the field, or from the scouts’ position, for those who simply want to watch the birds, or to be more exact, scare them with sticks, noise and handkerchiefs, so that they take flight and are exposed. The activity can be complemented with a picnic lunch with a chance to sample some of the fabulous local produce.

You must not only aim right, but draw the bow with all your might

– Henry David Thoreau, Philosopher and Naturist (1817-1862) –

experiences.name: Nature
experiences.description: You can find nature in Spain in every single corner. Let us bring you to the most impressive ones and get to know about our support to sustainable tourism.

destinations.name: Madrid
destinations.description: Madrid, the heart of Spain. Its vast history, aristocratic character, cultural diversity and cosmopolitan soul permeate the psyche of the “Madrileños” on the streets...

fields.intro: Imagine having lunch or dinner on a rooftop, with your own chef preparing a meal just for you, using organic produce picked straight from a secret urban garden!

flexible.wysiwyg: Madrid is a city known and admired for its vibrant terraces and stunning rooftops. It is no coincidence that the people of Madrid like to define their city with the famous phrase, ‘from Madrid to heaven!’ and, in line with the spirit of this ‘motto’, one of the oldest and most elegant hotels in Madrid decided, four years ago, to create an urban garden on its rooftop. It has since become a point of reference for advertising shoots, company events, product presentations and press conferences.

With the recent opening of an innovative rooftop COCINA (kitchen), the venue now also offers gastronomic experiences. We can enjoy the organic and natural offerings from this garden, with a lunch or dinner cooked on the spot and enjoyed in private. Along with the hotel’s chef, we can participate in everything from a ‘master chef’ class in which we make original dishes using products from the garden, to a more ‘sit back and relax’ show-cooking experience, where we will see how the chef prepares and explains his most exquisite creations, whilst enjoying a glass of wine or champagne.

You don’t have to cook fancy or sophisticated masterpieces – just good food from fresh ingredients

– Julie Child, cook (1912-2004) –

related.post_title: Flamenco & Madrid - A World Conquering Partnership

experiences.name: Nature
experiences.description: You can find nature in Spain in every single corner. Let us bring you to the most impressive ones and get to know about our support to sustainable tourism.

destinations.name: Madrid
destinations.description: Madrid, the heart of Spain. Its vast history, aristocratic character, cultural diversity and cosmopolitan soul permeate the psyche of the “Madrileños” on the streets...

fields.intro: Time together as a family away from normal daily stress and routine is something to be treasured. Let us make it even more special.

flexible.wysiwyg:
Sometimes we forget how important it is to travel as a FAMILIA (family), apart from enjoying time together, it allows us to get to know a holiday destination from a different perspective. This is especially true for the youngest members of the family, and in Madrid, Faunia is definitely one of those spaces that are designed to be enjoyed by all.

This 14-hectare park, with four ecosystems and 19 thematic areas, is home to more than 3,000 animals from 300 different species, each with its own habitat, temperature, light conditions and humidity. Here we can find everything from the extreme cold of Antarctica to the tropical heat of the Amazon rainforest, from the mysterious world of the nocturnal animals to the elegant butterfly kingdom and its majestic woodlands.

In the company of a biologist or botanist, Spain Collection offers a family program to discover the secrets of the animal and plant world, so well represented in this space. Discover the polar ecosystem with a private visit to the penguin colony with one its caretakers or take a dive with fur seals.  Swim with these very sociable and friendly mammals and see first-hand how they differ from seals or sea lions.

The family can feed manatees and giraffes, interact with pelicans and koalas, or see and touch reptiles and dolphins up close, all under the guidance of the venue’s experts, who will make sure the whole family has a fantastic time. The activity can be complemented by a photographer who will accompany you during the tour and make a personalized book of photos of your visit.

The love for all living creatures is the most noble attribute of man

– Charles Darwin,  naturalist, geologist and biologist (1809-1882) –

experiences.name: Body & Soul
experiences.description: Life can get hectic sometimes, so treat yourself with Spain's spas and other plans to wind down like yoga and mindfulness healing.

destinations.name: Madrid
destinations.description: Madrid, the heart of Spain. Its vast history, aristocratic character, cultural diversity and cosmopolitan soul permeate the psyche of the “Madrileños” on the streets...

fields.intro: Traveling should not have to mean interrupting your exercise routines and or putting your health-conscious lifestyle on hold… Put your sneakers on, we've got a city to explore!

flexible.wysiwyg:
Engaging in physical activity on a daily basis has a number of health benefits, ranging from increased life expectancy, better quality sleep, stronger bones and muscles to weight control, better blood sugar and insulin levels, and reduced risk of cardiovascular disease, as well as certain types of cancer. In addition, recent studies have shown that physical activity also improves our mental health and general mood, as well as optimising thought processes, and improving memory and learning skills.

If doing sport is healthy for our body and mind, and for many it is a way of life, why should we give up this habit while on vacation? We can design a completely personalised physical-activity plan for your stay in Madrid. A personal trainer will accompany you every day with a routine adapted to your needs.  A morning run in the capital can include some of the city’s most emblematic sights and a yoga or Tai Chi class can be organised on one of the city’s many rooftop terraces.

Finish off your daily exercise with a healthy DESAYUNO (breakfast) or brunch to replenish your energy levels. This can be vegan, vegetarian, or prepared using exclusively organic products. A nutritionist can design a food plan adapted to your tastes, special dietary requirements or objectives.

The man who has no imagination has no wings

– Muhammad Ali, boxer (1942-2016) –
