experiences.description: The Knights Templar, the Jesuits, Islam, the Sephardic legacy, the history of the Moors, none of these can be studied or better understood without setting foot in Spain or Portugal.

destinations.name: Madrid
destinations.description: Madrid, the heart of Spain. Its vast history, aristocratic character, cultural diversity and cosmopolitan soul permeate the psyche of the “Madrileños” on the streets...

fields.intro: Both Madrid and Toledo have been the capital of Spain. A stroll around their historic quarters will provide a wider sense of understanding of Spain’s religious heritage.

flexible.wysiwyg: Madrid, the capital city of Spain is unarguably one of the most interesting cities for those seeking to learn more about the religious heritage of Spain. Not only is the city full of very interesting churches and monasteries but there is also a modern yet majestic Cathedral, La Almudena, right next door to the Royal Palace. Let our curators walk with you through the narrow streets of the medieval old quarter of Madrid and let them unveil the secrets of some off-the-beaten-track places such as the Convent of Las Descalzas Reales or the biggest dome in Spain at the Basilica de San Francisco El Grande, a neoclassical gem with works by masters Goya and Zurbaran.

Just a high-speed train away is the Imperial city of Toledo, declared a world heritage city by UNESCO back in 1986. Toledo is a unique city in the world where Islam, Judaism and Christianity had a harmonious and productive coexistence for centuries. No other place has such a vast amount of history within such a small area. Wander its labyrinth-like streets with us and be amazed by the architecture laid out first by the Moors later becoming home to the most influential Jewish community in Spain, the Sephardic. Toledo then became the center for Christianity in the world in the 16th century. The expert eye of our historian will guide you through the most important sites in Toledo. We can arrange private visits of some of the former mosques and synagogues and even organise a private organ concert at the impressive gothic Cathedral. Let us show you 2,000 years of history and culture, in a city that timeless masters such as painter El Greco or flamenco guitar icon Paco de Lucia called home.

 

Peace is the highest religion. Peace is the glory of humanity

― Amit Ray, Author and spiritual master. Born 1960 ―

related.post_title: Toledo: The Art of Damascening & Sword-making

1541.title: Mystics: St.Teresa & St. John Of The Cross

experiences.name: Religious Heritage
experiences.description: The Knights Templar, the Jesuits, Islam, the Sephardic legacy, the history of the Moors, none of these can be studied or better understood without setting foot in Spain or Portugal.

destinations.name: Madrid
destinations.description: Madrid, the heart of Spain. Its vast history, aristocratic character, cultural diversity and cosmopolitan soul permeate the psyche of the “Madrileños” on the streets...

fields.intro: Tracing the footsteps of these two saints we relive the history of Spain’s most significant religious and literary events from the 16th century.

flexible.wysiwyg:
The history of religious literature would not be complete without references to two of the great Castilian spiritual guides – Saint Teresa of Avila or Saint John of the Cross. ‘The Spiritual Canticle’ by Saint John of the Cross or ‘The Interior Castle’ by Saint Teresa are amongst the jewels of world literature. Our experts will explain the works and miracles of two of the most famous saints in the world.  We will learn about the customs of 16th Century Spain and visit the monasteries where they lived a contemplative life full of prayer. Both were instrumental in the Carmelite reform of the Catholic Church, one of the most important reforms in the history of the Catholic Church which led to the foundation of numerous CONVENTOS (convents) throughout Spain.

Just one hour from Madrid we have the UNESCO cities of Avila and Segovia, where both saints are venerated.  The two cities have amazing monasteries, secluded churches and stunning cathedrals to be discovered. The lives and experiences of Teresa and John also reached cities like Toledo and further south across La Mancha and on to Adalusia, we can find the lovely, quaint villages of Ubeda and Baeza, also UNESCO sites, where Saint John spent the last years of his intense life. For the most devout, there will be no lack of moments for prayer in the places where their remains now rest, both places of pilgrimage for millions of faithful from all over the world.

If a man wishes to be sure of the road he’s traveling on, then he must close his eyes and travel in the dark

― St. John of the Cross. Saint and mystic writer. (1542-1591) ―

experiences.name: Religious Heritage
experiences.description: The Knights Templar, the Jesuits, Islam, the Sephardic legacy, the history of the Moors, none of these can be studied or better understood without setting foot in Spain or Portugal.

fields.intro: The impressive abbey of Montserrat is home to one of the most spiritual places in Spain. This unique site is revered by spiritualists, nature lovers, and archeologists the world over...

flexible.wysiwyg:
Montserrat is one of those unique places in the world where you feel both connected with your spiritual self and amazed by the capricious beauty of nature at its best. The multi-peaked mountain range of Montserrat is quite extraordinary with its jagged, saw -mountains formed by ‘needles’ of monolithic rocks which vary hugely in their shape and form.

It’s hard to believe a Benedictine community has led a monastic life in this area for almost one thousand years! Montserrat has been a prominent Marian shrine since the 9th century, when legend has it that a wooden image of the Virgin Mary was found in a CUEVA (cave) in the foothills of the mountain. Today’s image, a black Madonna, known as ‘La Moreneta’, dates back to the 12th century. and is still venerated by millions of pilgrims every year. The monks of the abbey are also known across the world for their choir.  The boys’ choir or ‘escolania’, is one of the oldest of its kind in Europe with documents referencing a school of music in Montserrat in the 14th century. The angelic voices of the boys have captivated millions of pilgrims and they have been invited to perform all around the world.

To top it all off, Montserrat has a small and intimate museum.  One of a kind, the exhibits are an array of pieces from very different periods, with Catalan modernist painters such as Ramon Casas, displayed next to an academic, classic painting from a 13-year-old Picasso, and then right around the corner you’ll find a Caravaggio next to a masterpiece from Salvador Dalí…

Our curators will immerse you in an unforgettable experience in one of the most beautiful areas of Catalonia.

Certain places try to tell us something, or have said something we should not have missed

– Jorge Luis Borges writer (1889-1986) –

fields.intro: The Monastery of Poblet is a jewel hidden in the mountains of Tarragona. It is one of the largest and most complete Cistersian abbeys in the world.

flexible.wysiwyg:
Located in the Sierra de Montsant, in Tarragona, the Royal Monastery of Santa Maria de Poblet, one of the best examples of Cistercian Monasteries and declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1991, is one of the most important architectural complexes in Europe from the Middle Ages. Founded in 1151, the monastery was always under the protection of the Crown of Aragon and the most important noble families of the time. In 1340 the Royal Pantheon was built where royals and noblemen from the 14th and 15th centuries are buried. Today it is home to 25 Benedictine monks. We propose a visit with a monk from the monastery, to see its main chapel, the library, the wine cellar, and museum.

The good and the wise lead quiet lives

– Euripides – Greek Tragedian –

1565.title: Barcelona and Girona: Sephardic Heritage in Catalonia

experiences.name: Religious Heritage
experiences.description: The Knights Templar, the Jesuits, Islam, the Sephardic legacy, the history of the Moors, none of these can be studied or better understood without setting foot in Spain or Portugal.

destinations.name: Barcelona
destinations.description: This great Mediterranean metropolis is Modernism, is Gaudi, is a design hub, is the Gothic Quarter, is the Ramblas and the Sea Promenade, is light and is sun.

fields.intro: Step back in time and discover the medieval architecture of Barcelona, and combine it with a visit of the city of Girona which is an absolute medieval gem full of wonderfully preserved architectural marvels.

flexible.wysiwyg:
The city of Barcelona is without a doubt one of the most intriguing places in Spain with 2,000 years of history nestled between the Collserola mountains and the Mediterranean Sea. From the Romans to Gaudi, the cultural and historical heritage is vast in Catalonia. Up to the 16th Century, the region was home to a thriving Jewish community. Their legacy is of tremendous importance with much of it still visible today.

There is no denial that the history of the Jewish population of Spain, or Sephardic Jews, is full of illustrious episodes as tragic ones, concluding with the most tragic of them all, the edict of expulsion sanctioned by King Ferdinand I of Aragon and Queen Isabel I of Castille in 1492. In Catalonia, the city of Barcelona, and just one hour north, the town of Girona, are two of the most important Jewish heritage sites in Spain. They both preserve old Jewish quarters or ‘Call‘ in Catalan, and many of the labyrinth-like streets of these areas have kept the old names of the many guilds and businesses that once thrived here. Our Sephardic expert will immerse you in the ancient Sepharad culture and its many contributions to daily life at that time. Visit the Jewish quarter in Barcelona with over 600 years of history, or uncover their fascinating history in Girona as we stroll around the maze of medieval cobblestone street and patios of Girona’s Jewish Call.

The 20th century brought a new dawn for Sephardic Jews in Spain, and the importance and reconciliation is such that the government is granting citizenship to all those wgo are able to every to trace back their Sephardic ancestry. Let us offer you the chance to reconnect with the present communities in Barcelona and join the celebration of Sabbath with the locals at one of the most active Jewish Synagogues in Spain.

Additionally, why not take a moment to walk down the iconic staircase of Girona’s Cathedral and relive the moment Jaime Lannister tries to prevent the walk of shame of Queen Margaery in Game of Thrones – several episodes of this iconic TV series were filmed in the city’s old quarter.

A mind needs books just like a sword needs whetstone

– Tyrion Lannister, Counselor of Queen Daenerys Targaryen (Games of Thrones) –

fields.intro: The city of Barcelona is, for many, named after its football club and not the other way around. If you’re a football fan there’s no way you can be in Barcelona and not visit Camp Nou, the iconic stadium of the ‘blue and reds’.

flexible.wysiwyg: F.C. Barcelona is one of the top football teams in the world and a city icon. Their museum is the most visited in Catalonia and some of their games are the main reason people come to the city. Spain Collection offers a variety of hospitality options for travelers who wish to enjoy a PARTIDO (soccer game), such as grandstand seats, access to private boxes, hospitality or a private visit of the club’s museum etc.

For small parties with a generous budget we can arrange some of the most exclusive activities any fan could wish for: the chance to witness a team training session, a meet and greet with current and former players, and even tickets to Leo Messi’s private box to watch a game alongside his family and friends.

Playing football is very simple, but playing simple football is the hardest thing there is

– Johan Cruyff 1947-2016 –

fields.intro: The Barcelona-Catalunya Montmeló Circuit is legendary and so can your F1 experience with us!

flexible.wysiwyg: The Catalunya Montmeló Circuit in Barcelona has been home to the Spanish Formula 1 Grand Prix since 1991, and is the headquarters of several F1 teams who use the facilities for year-round training purposes. Attend the F1 race with transfer to the circuit by helicopter, get tickets to the paddock, have a meet and greet with racing team members, plus enjoy services such as private catering, access to the boxes, a chauffeur and on-site concierge. Alternatively, if you prefer to view a team practice session or better still, race round the Montmeló track yourself in a BOLIDO (racing car), Spain Collection can arrange for some unforgettable adrenaline-filled experiences.

I remember the year 2000, I drove the Benetton here with the Enstone guys. Now, in 2020, it’s with Renault, so it’s a special track and I have lots of good memories here. It’s a track I know very well, so it’s been a good day

– Fernando Alonso, F1 Driver. Born 1981 –

fields.intro: Are you ready to experience some real adrenaline? MotoGP races are constantly pushing boundaries, and with the current crop of Spanish riders regularly making it to the podium, there’s no better place to experience a race than Barcelona!

flexible.wysiwyg: For those racing fans for whom 4 wheels are just too many, you don’t need to be a renegade to enjoy your passion on just two. Spain and Portugal have world-class racetracks and Spain Collection can provide the ultimate in MotoGP racing experiences just for you. From Mediterranean facilities in Barcelona or Valencia, to the iconic CIRCUITOS (tracks) in Jerez or Estoril, our experts will get you pit-lane access to feel the roaring engines and see the racing stars up close. For die-hard fans with gasoline running through their veins, some circuits are available for private hire so you can feel like Valentino Rossi or Marc Marquez for a day in the company of our experts and professional instructors. I wait until I see God, then I know it’s time to break

fields.intro: Catalonia has some of the best restaurants in the world. Here is where the whole concept of cuisine was transformed, where the first laboratory of modern cuisine was created.

flexible.wysiwyg:
Barcelona tops the list of Michelin-starred restaurants in Spain with a total of 29 restaurants and 38 stars. Abac, Lasarte, Tickets, Alkimia, Hisop – these are all names on every gourmet’s wishlist and some of them offer unique visits to the chef’s sanctuary: the kitchen.

For determined foodies with a proper bucket list to accomplish the Celler de Can Roca will probably sit at the very top. This exceptional restaurant is located in Sant Celoni, an hour away from Barcelona, and it doesn’t really need any type of introduction beyond mentioning that it has 3 times been rated number one restaurant in the world and 5 times rated number two.  It became a 3 star Michelin in 2009 and hasn’t lost a star since. The HERMANOS (brothers) Roca are the leaders of this Church for gastronomy and we at Spain Collection can arrange a night here to remember.

The kitchen is transversal. It can be used to explain physics, language, history…

– Ferran Adrià, Chef, born 1962 –

fields.intro: Catalonia is a paradise for wine lovers. It’s a land with an exuberant wine culture, where every area produces wines each with their own fully-rounded personality.

flexible.wysiwyg: There are two main D.O. wine regions (D.O. denotes quality wine from a designated area) on the outskirts of Barcelona: Priorat and Penedés. Whether you fancy Cava or wine there are numerous cellars in the area that will cater for a private visit and tour; that said only a few grant an exclusive and fully-immersive experience and Spain Collection is here to go the extra mile. Meet the winery owner, discover the story behind the TIERRA (land), learn from the most highly-regarded sommeliers and experience harvesting being as much hands-on as you want. Wrap the day up with a meal amongst the vines and indulge in a gourmet feast orchestrated by our Ambassador, chef Eneko Atxa.

If you prefer to discover areas more off-the-beaten track we will surprise you with the wine region of Alella. Located north of Barcelona and by the sea, the ‘Modernist’ vineyards here have learned to take advantage of the Mediterranean salt in the air to grow their vines; if you want unique, we’re here to deliver.

He who knows how to taste, does not drink wine but savors secrets.

– Salvador Dalí, Artist (1904-1989) –

fields.intro: Catalan cuisine is known the world over for its creativity and the high quality of its produce, not surprising, therefore,that it is home to some of the best restaurants in the world.

flexible.wysiwyg: Catalonia is a region of great gastronomic wealth both in terms of its produce and in terms of its recipes and innovation which has been in a constant state of development over the last few decades thanks to the efforts of chefs who have revolutionized the world of cuisine everywhere. Come and discover, with our collection curators, a research space dedicated to cooking, a place where food and science combine to teach us how to eat in a healthier way. It is called the Alicia Foundation and is located in the vicinity of the Sant Benet Monastery, one of the best-preserved monastic complexes dating from the Middle Ages in Catalonia.

Attend a show-cooking workshop about Catalan cuisine with an anthropologist specialized in food heritage, and a professional chef who will show you different Catalan dishes explaining our culinary traditions along the way. This is a great activity for kids because not only do they get really hands-on during the workshop, but because the idyllic environment here means activities such as trekking and biking can also be incorporated into the best day ever!

There is no sincerer love than the love of food

– George Bernard Shaw, Playright (1856-1950) –

fields.intro: Catalonia’s human towers are truly a spectacle to behold. A unique expression of Catalan history and identity, the Castells were declared Intangible Cultural Heritage by UNESCO in 2010.
fields.intro_mobile: Catalonia’s human towers are truly a spectacle to behold. A unique expression of Catalan history and identity, the Castells were declared Intangible Cultural Heritage by UNESCO in 2010.

flexible.wysiwyg: Castells or human towers are one of Catalonia’s most traditional spectacles. It is said that they date back to the 15th century. The first documented performance is from 2nd February 1801 during the Festival of the Virgen de la Candela in Valls (Tarragona). Thanks to their popular appeal and the motivation of the castellers themselves to make their human towers ever higher and more original, the Castells were declared Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity by UNESCO in 2010.

Spain Collection invites you to get to know one of the most renowned ‘collas’ (human tower groups) in Catalonia and train with them. Experience the strength of their spirit of collaboration and learn first-hand about their history. And don’t worry, this adrenaline-filled activity will adhere to all the necessary safety measures – your well-being is paramount to us! The most important ‘collas’ are located in the Penedes area so we can combine this activity with a fabulous, traditional lunch afterwards.

Força, equilibri, valor i seny (Strength, balance values and sobriety)

–  Casteller proverb –

fields.intro: Stained glass is one of the oldest forms of art, where glass, colour and light combine to create impressive narratives.

flexible.wysiwyg: In the Middle Ages, Catalonia was known for its trades and crafts, especially in glass. Stained-glass windows for churches and cathedrals were designed here, and they often represented scenes of daily life and spirituality. The oldest examples found in Catalonia are from the glassworks of the monastery of the Santas Creus, one of the largest monasteries in Catalonia which dates from the 13th century. In Barcelona, we can still find different ateliers dedicated to this ancient art that has been passed on from generation to generation. Discover with Spain Collection one of the most famous workshops that has been involved in the construction of the Sagrada Familia and is involved in the restoration of great stained-glass masterpieces from across our country. Discover emblematic places through the most important glasswork craftsmen in Catalonia.

The true work of art is but a shadow of divine perfection.

– Michelangelo Buonarroti, Artist, (1475-1564) –

1693.title: Gaudi: Walking in The Footsteps of a Genius

experiences.name: Culture
experiences.description: Spain and Portugal combined have more UNESCO World Heritage Sites than any other place in the world.

destinations.name: Barcelona
destinations.description: This great Mediterranean metropolis is Modernism, is Gaudi, is a design hub, is the Gothic Quarter, is the Ramblas and the Sea Promenade, is light and is sun.

fields.intro: Gaudi, the genius of Modernist architecture, was a revolutionary Catalan artist who incorporated nature’s geometry into wondrous shapes and buildings known and admired today across the world.

flexible.wysiwyg: Antoni Gaudi i Cornet is our country’s most famous architect, he was a genius who revolutionized architecture and the plastic arts. The examples of his work in our region are a wonderful representation of the Modernist art movement of Catalonia. Gaudi had a strong connection with and admiration for his homeland and the Mediterranean. He was born in Reus, in southern Catalonia, where he fell in love with the wonders of the natural world and the traditional crafts of the region. He loved walking in the mountains, and well into his old age he would walk over 6 miles every day. Gaudi’s life was mainly centered in Barcelona and its surroundings, it was here where he developed his most important projects, each very different in style but always influenced by the forms and structures of nature.

The construction of his great masterpiece, the Sagrada Familia, began in 1886, and is still ongoing following Gaudi’s plans with computer technology now helping to translate his designs for today’s craftsmen. Discover the life of Gaudi from a more intimate perspective to better understand his life and works. We will take you to see some of his lesser-known projects as well his last place of residence and places he used to frequent.

Originality consists of returning to the origin. Thus, originality means returning, through resources, to the simplicity of the early solutions.

–Antoni Gaudí, Architect (1852-1926) –

1715.title: The Ground-Breaking Eccentricity of Salvador Dali

experiences.name: Culture
experiences.description: Spain and Portugal combined have more UNESCO World Heritage Sites than any other place in the world.

destinations.name: Barcelona
destinations.description: This great Mediterranean metropolis is Modernism, is Gaudi, is a design hub, is the Gothic Quarter, is the Ramblas and the Sea Promenade, is light and is sun.

fields.intro: Salvador Dalí, an artist known for his eccentric personality, created some of the last century’s most innovative works of art.

flexible.wysiwyg: One of the most internationally representative figures of European surrealism is Salvador Dali. Dali was hugely extravagant, and without doubt, someone with one of the most open minds of that era in our country. Everything was done in excess and wild hallucinations led him to create art that knew no boundaries. In both his works of art and properties that he owned you can see the extravagance of his day to day, from the most traditional to the most contemporary.

Dalí was a great fan of the Costa Brava, in the north of Catalonia, where most of his residences are located. The most emblematic is in Port Lligat, a small town where he had 3 white houses by the sea. It’s a paradise of tranquillity and it’s where the artist and his wife Gala made their home. Explore his homes with us, and the town where he lived most of his life where many neighbors and local businesses still remember him and share moments from the artist’s life with us.

The true painter must be able, with the most usual things, to have the most unusual ideas.

– Salvador Dalí, Artist (1904-1989) –

fields.intro: Pablo Picasso began to show his prodigal talent as a child. He did not disappoint. By the end of his life he was one of the most acclaimed artists of the 20th century.

flexible.wysiwyg:
Picasso is without a doubt one of Spain’s most famous artists. ‘Las Señoritas de Avignon’, painted when he was only 25 years old, changed the history of art and was the start of his incredible career as a painter. Picasso showed great artistic talent from a very young age and went on to become one of the best painters in the world, and an icon of the 21st century.

He was born in southern Spain, in Malaga, but it was in Barcelona where he began his career as a modernist painter. Visit the museum with an expert curator on Picasso’s work and visit the places the painter frequented in the city to learn more about his beginnings as an artist.

To flourish, a work of art must ignore or rather forget all the rules

– Pablo Picasso, Artist, (1881.1973) –

flexible.wysiwyg: Barcelona is a dream come true for those that love to shop.  It’s a cosmopolitan city bursting with talent and creativity. The variety of brands, styles and prices is endless. Each area offers a different experience, but they all connect with the soul of Barcelona. In Borne, one of the city’s oldest neighborhoods, we have small boutiques with national and foreign brands. Along Paseo de Gracia, Barcelona’s luxury boulevard, you’ll find top international brands. In the neighborhoods of Gracia or Poblenou you’ll find more local shops and art galleries…

Our personal shopper will design a bespoke shopping experience to include the brands that are closest to your tastes. and will also give you tips on the styles, colors and cuts that suit you best. Let me say here how much I love Barcelona, an admirable city, a city full of life, intense, a port open to the past and the future

flexible.wysiwyg: Paseo de Gracia is one of Barcelona’s most famous boulevards not only because of the incredible architecture of the buildings that line it but because it condenses, into its 1300-meter length, the top end of the city’s luxury retail and hotel establishments. Santa Eulalia, three floors of multi-brand exquisiteness, is one of the street’s highlights that has led the way in the concept of ’boutique’ shopping in Barcelona since 1901. It is a magical place where words like ‘style’ or ‘beauty’ become tangible objects. It’s a mandatory stop for anyone interested in a high-end shopping experience. That is why Spain Collection has prepared something truly exclusive for those who are looking for something more than just pretty handbags and expensive clothes: handmade shirts, expert style advice, bespoke tailoring, catering, music… in private, all just for you. Everyone will want to live it, but only a few will have the opportunity to talk about it!

Fashion has two purposes: comfort and love. Beauty comes when fashion succeeds

fields.intro: La Garrotxa is one of most best-preserved volcanic areas in Europe with over 40 inactive volcanoes. A region of spectacular natural beauty to discover along with many culinary and cultural delights.

flexible.wysiwyg:
The great variety of landscapes that Catalonia offers, along with the region’s heritage and history, attract millions of tourists every year, many returning year after year unable to resist the beauty of this area. The Costa Brava is, in particular, one of the Mediterranean’s best treasures, with the Pyrenees and its prolific mountains and lakes, picturesque villages and natural parks, plus the volcanic region of La Garrotxa…

The area of La Garrotxa is known for its medieval villages, its gastronomy, its scenery and for the Volcanic Natural Park, one of the best-preserved volcanic landscapes in Europe, with 40 inactive volcanoes.

Hot air ballooning is an early bird activity because we need calm winds and cold air. On a clear day we may be able to see the Mediterranean Sea and the Pyrenees! Have a cup of hot chocolate whilst enjoying the sensation of floating above the earth, and relish the peace and serenity.

Explore the nature, heritage and traditions of this area with our collection curators and stay in exclusive hotels surrounded by nature and charm.

When the walker enters this place, he begins to walk slowly; count his steps in great stillness

– Joan Maragall, Poet (1860-1911) –

fields.intro: The idyllic island of Mallorca has a wonderful Mediterranean cuisine to explore and the locals take great pride in preserving their culinary traditions. Find out more with Spain Collection.

flexible.wysiwyg:
The island of Mallorca is the largest of the Balearic Islands and boasts a typical Mediterranean landscape of beaches with crystalline waters and densely forested mountains.

Mallorca also has a strong gastronomic tradition such as sobrasada, not at all suitable for vegans as it is a cured raw sausage! Ensaimadas, a sweet pastry, are ideal for breakfast served with a coffee. Wines and cheeses abound, and then there are traditional dishes such as Tumbet or Coca de Trampo. Discovering the gastronomy of the island from a local and sustainable perspective, we will visit a local orchard and vegetable garden, learn about the production of organic wine and go to a farm where the most typical products of the island are produced.

The beauty of traveling and eating in different cultures is looking for the good in each place, the new, and enjoying the moment

– Ferran Adrià. Chef. Born 1962 –

fields.intro: A stereotypical image of the Canary Islands would be that of sandy beaches and endless sunshine. But cliches are not our style. At Spain Collection we want to share with you the essence of the often referred to 'Fortunate isles'.
fields.intro_mobile: A stereotypical image of the Canary Islands would be that of sandy beaches and endless sunshine. But cliches are not our style. At Spain Collection we want to share with you the essence of the often referred to 'Fortunate isles'.

flexible.wysiwyg: The Canaries are known for their bananas, a fruit introduced to the islanders by the Portuguese explorers on their voyages from Equatorial Guinea. The climate here is ideal for growing bananas as the warm temperatures, cool breeze, and almost constant sunshine let the plants grow in perfect conditions. They are about half the size of a Caribbean or South American banana but arguably pack in much more flavour and are sweeter.

Banana plantations are surprisingly magical places, especially at sunset when the last rays of the day filter through the dense foliage of the palms. So, let us take you to an incredible banana plantation for a delicious dinner prepared exclusively for you. A unique evening, and an unforgettable experience.

Agriculture is the art of knowing how to wait

– Anonymous –

fields.intro: Spectacular, inspiring, mind blowing...Sublimotion is both an experience and performance, it is an unforgettable gastro-sensory journey.

flexible.wysiwyg: Ibiza is one of Europe’s top holiday destinations. Every summer the ‘white island’ welcomes some of the world’s most demanding visitors who are looking for mind-blowing experiences. The Hard Rock Hotel and its parent hotel, Ushuaia, are two of the trendiest hotels on the island, and they organise some of the best parties in the Mediterranean, if not, the world. In 2014 the hotel chain decided to create an incredible experience to surpass even the highest expectations …. and that’s how Sublimotion came into being. Run by Michelin-star chef, Paco Roncero, this is the most expensive restaurant in the world. Yet Sublimotion is not just another restaurant, it’s akin to entering inside someone’s imagination where the latest advancements in cuisine, cinema and technology fuse together to create a unique culinary adventure that never ceases to surprise the diner. So expect the unexpected and be ready to participate in this unforgettable dining experience.

Creativity is intelligence having fun

– Albert Einstein Theoretical Physicist 1879-1955 –

fields.intro: The White Island. It is often said that what happens in Ibiza stays in Ibiza. Endless nights filled with endless parties.

flexible.wysiwyg:
The island of Ibiza is known the world over for its dazzling sunsets and thundering nightlife. Arguably some of the best nightclubs in the world are located here and year after year music artists and DJs flock to the island, along with partygoers from around the world.

Daytime we suggest a day at the beach with VIP access to one of the best beach clubs on the island or spend a day on a chartered YATE (yacht) with gourmet catering and DJ on board.  Night-time we will pick you up in a chauffeur-driven car and drop you at LIO CLUB, one of the best clubs on the island. You will have VIP access to this spectacular water-edge venue which includes a restaurant, cabaret and nightclub.

Top off your nightlife experience and dance the night away with access to the VIP areas of other exclusive clubs such as Pacha, Amnesia, Ushuaia, and depending on the DJ in charge that night, a meet and greet in their booth will be in order!

It’s all about respect, respect to the music, respect to the DJ’s, respect to the crowd and respect to each other. It’s all music, music never separates people!

– Carl Cox, DJ and Producer born 1962 –

destinations.name: Balearic & Canary Islands
destinations.description: Mallorca, Tenerife, Ibiza, Lanzarote, Menorca … it’s impossible to sum up the islands in a couple of sentences when they are all so unique in their own right...

fields.intro: Beyond the beautiful beaches and pulsating nightlife discover lesser-known island crafted delicacies.

flexible.wysiwyg:
For many the island of Ibiza is synonymous with nightlife, but the truth is that the party side of the island accounts for barely 10% of what this Mediterranean paradise can offer. The interior of Ibiza is home to a number of farms and venues which offer luxury eco-tourism activities and where you can immerse yourself in Balearic traditions such as creating your own herb liqueur or making your very own version of the world-renowned Ibizan sea salt.

Hierbas (herb liqueur) is made from various herbs that grow around the island. It’s usually served as a digestif after lunch or dinner. The liqueur dates back to the 1880s, when a farmer on the neighbouring island of Formentera wanted to make use of the natural properties and benefits of the herbs that naturally grew on the island.  Learn about the production of this liqueur and journey through the island’s culture and history.  Stimulate your senses as you smell and taste each of the herbs used whilst you make your very own blend to take home.

The salt produced in Ibiza is obtained by traditional harvesting methods and it arrives at your table untouched by any kind of refining process. It retains more than 80 essential minerals and trace elements, all of which are essential for the human organism.

Let food be medicine and medicine be food

– Hippocrates, Physician 460-370 bc –

fields.intro: Ibiza has long been a place for inspiration. The hippie movement back in the 1960s was one of the most revolutionary moments, in cultural terms, of the last century. Ibiza is where 'boho chic' started.

flexible.wysiwyg: Hippie fashion around the world was inspired by Ibiza.  The island’s boho chic has influenced brands and celebrities alike. Ibiza inspires a certain style, elegance and freshness influenced by the Mediterranean summer. Leave the beach behind for a day and get to know the artisan roots of Ibiza and how they’re still influencing trends today. See how ‘espardenyes’ (espadrilles) are made, discover the hippie markets, and the most emblematic places of the hippie movement from when the island was first ‘discovered’ in the 1970s.  To finish the day, we will take you to the best-known store on the island to see where the latest trends in ‘boho chic’ are headed. The route around the island will be by 2CV, the iconic car of choice for the hippies!

Fashion is not something that exists in dresses only. Fashion is in the sky, in the street, fashion has to do with ideas, the way we live, what is happening

– Coco Chanel, Fashion Designer, 1883-1971 –

fields.intro: Setting foot on the island of Mallorca is like stepping into the essence of the Mediterranean, with its beautiful clear light, the vibrant blue of the sky, the crystal-clear waters of the sea and the lush green forests of the mountains.

flexible.wysiwyg: In Mallorca we have one of the most original forms of textile production in Spain. The production process is known as ‘Clothes of Tongues’ which is based on the technique of weaving ikat. These fabrics arrived in Mallorca from southeast Asia via the Silk Route. Mallorca is one of the few places in Europe where you can still find this type of high-quality fabric. We will visit the workshop where these fabrics are made, a family business founded in 1854 and dedicated to the production and conservation of traditional Mallorcan textiles. It’s a fabric that is widely used across the ISLA (island) in people’s homes, shops and businesses. It embodies the essence and character of the Mediterranean.

Fashion is very important. It is life-enhancing and, like everything that gives pleasure, it is worth doing well

– Vivienne Westwood, Fashion Designer, Born 1941 –

fields.intro: The landscapes of Mallorca are breath-taking: valleys, mountains, the water, secret coves and hidden caves.

flexible.wysiwyg: The mountains of Mallorca offer lush Mediterranean landscapes for outdoor pursuits whether you’re in great physical shape or simply want to be out doing something active. We have two fantastic options for you. The first being the island of Cabrera, an uninhabited archipelago with untamed nature, caves and the ruins of ancient castles that can only be reached by boat. The second being the stunning Sierra de Tramuntana, a mountainous enclave declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO for its history, culture and environmental significance. The Sierra de Tramuntana offers unrivalled viewpoints from which to contemplate the sunset, discover fairy-tale stone villages and enjoy fabulous local restaurants in secluded locations.

There is pleasure in the pathless woods, there is rapture in the lonely shore, there is society where none intrudes, by the deep sea, and music in its roar; I love not Man the less, but Nature more

– Lord Byron, Poet, (1788-1824) –

fields.intro: Up in the Tramuntana mountains lies the path to the Lluc Sanctuary, Mallorca’s most sacred site and one of the most beautiful and idyllic places on the island.

flexible.wysiwyg: The Lluc Sanctuary has long been an important place of pilgrimage, built in the 17th century to venerate the black Virgin, ‘La Moreneta’. Local legend has it that Lluc, the son of a local farmer, found a wooden figure of the Virgin Mary in the forest which he decided to donate to the local church. The curious thing is that the same figure kept mysteriously reappearing to him at the place where he had originally found it. Eventually it was decided that they would build a sanctuary at that place in the forest.

On Sundays the children of the choir school, Escolania ‘Blauets’, whose origins can be traced back to the 16th century, sing at the Sanctuary. Our travel curators will tailor-make a pilgrimage route to the Sanctuary for you with a local expert. Contemplate the wonderful mountain landscape of Mallorca and learn about the life of the monks of the monastery.

Jesus teaches us another way: Go out. Go out and share your testimony, go out and interact with your brothers, go out and share, go out and ask. Become the Word in body as well as spirit

– Pope Francis, born 1936 –

flexible.wysiwyg:
The rural interior of Ibiza is missed by most visitors to the island as they head straight for the coast, yet the countryside is, in many regards, as beautiful as the coastline. Quad-biking to some of the island’s hidden corners is great fun for the whole family.

Together with our local guides we will tour different areas of the island seeing local vineyards and farms, as well as visiting the small white villages in the heart of the island such as San Mateu or Santa Agnès. This tour allows you to get to know another side of the island and its beautiful Mediterranean landscape.

Then we will head to the coast where we will continue the adventure on jet skis and see the island from the water. We will also get to know its hidden beaches and sea caves.

We wrap up the day’s activity with a fabulous gourmet ‘farm-to-table’ meal at an off-the-beaten-track venue. An idyllic setting to enjoy with the whole family.

Twenty years from now you will be more disappointed by the things you didn’t do than by the ones you did do

– Mark Twain, Writer, 1835-1910 –

fields.intro: Spend an unforgettable evening with a Fado expert, a local who will share with you the tradition behind this uniquely Portuguese art form, as well as his own personal insights on this genre of singing listed as Intangible Cultural Heritage by UNESCO.

flexible.wysiwyg: Fado is often described as the musical expression of the Portuguese people, but it’s so much more than that. The best way to find out is first-hand, by spending the evening with a local Fado singer. Whether you stroll around the old quarter of Alfama or take the photogenic trolley car up to the popular neighborhood of Chiado, let our insider expert, Manuel, take you to a local Fado venue where the local singers hang out and sing their melancholic and heartfelt verses. As we sample some cod or some other traditional culinary Portuguese treat, he’ll explain the fascinating history behind this UNESCO-listed cultural heritage which is still very much alive, and part of Portugal’s make up even in the 21st Century. And of course, he will sing for us too.

The only thing that matters is to feel the fado. The fado is not meant to be sung; it simply happens. You feel it, you don’t understand it and you don’t explain it

– Amália Rodrigues. Fado singer (born 1920) –

fields.intro: Can you imagine that there could be so much history and tradition behind a simple pastry? Well, the pastel de nata is no simple pastry! With us you will discover why… and get ready to roll up your sleeves and attempt to make your own!
fields.intro_mobile: Can you imagine that there could be so much history and tradition behind a simple pastry? Well, the pastel de nata is no simple pastry! With us you will discover why… and get ready to roll up your sleeves and attempt to make your own!

flexible.wysiwyg:
The locals of Lisbon, or Lisboetas as they like to be called, are well known for their love of pastries and here, more than anywhere else, the pastel de nata is king. It was invented back in the 18th century, by monks at the Jerónimos Monastery in Belem, Lisbon. At that time, it was common practice to use egg whites to starch nuns’ habits — which, naturally, left the monks with a lot of leftover yolks.

To use them up, they began baking them into delicious, two-bite-sized custard tarts. Today, bakeries across Lisbon vie for the title of ‘best pastéis de nata in the city’. We’ll show you the iconic place rumored to be the keeper of the secret monks’ recipe since 1837, and with the memory of that perfectly baked ‘pastel’ we’ll head to a local cookery school, as it’s time for you to roll up your sleeves and prepare your very own ‘pasteis’ whilst hearing more stories of the Portuguese and their love of pastries!

A party without cake is just a meeting

– Julia Child – American cooking teacher (1946 – 1994) –

fields.intro_mobile: Just a short drive from the cobbled hills and buzz of Lisbon lies a remarkable winery set in a typical sleepy Portuguese village. Spend the day learning how the team here have turned this estate into a producer of top-quality wines garnering a number of international awards along the way.

flexible.wysiwyg: This idyllic, organic, working farm dates back to the 17th century.  The parents of the current owners bought it in the 1960s but abandoned the estate and left the country during the revolution in 1974. Much time and money were needed to return it to its former glory and the current owners finally moved back in full time in the early 90s. Since then it has gone from strength to strength.

The estate nestles in a diverse landscape of beautiful rolling hills and valleys.  A wonderful backdrop for wine tasting and wandering amongst the vines with the owner who will explain the specific viticulture and historical details of the landscape. To help soak up the wine we have the opportunity to ‘get stuck in’ with some bread making, all under strict supervision of the ladies from the village who have perfected this art over the last few decades.

Portugal has a peaceful feel about it. I sit on the terrace overlooking the vineyard there and I feel cut off from the world. You need that sort of thing

– Cliff Richard. Musician, Philanthropist (Born 1940) –

fields.intro: Discover with us one of the oldest and most famous traditions in Portugal: the art of tiles! Visit the National Tile Museum and its awe-inspiring collection of tiles and then set your inner creative free and decorate your own tile!
fields.intro_mobile: Discover with us one of the oldest and most famous traditions in Portugal: the art of tiles! Visit the National Tile Museum and its awe-inspiring collection of tiles and then set your inner creative free and decorate your own tile!

flexible.wysiwyg: When you think about Portugal, the beautiful ‘AZULEJOS’ (tiles) come to mind for sure. They are everywhere in Portugal. They decorate everything from walls of churches and monasteries, to palaces, ordinary houses, park seats, fountains, shops, and train stations. They often depict historic scenes, reproduce iconic sights and monuments, or simply serve as street signs, or house numbers.

The National Tile Museum is housed within the walls of a former convent with collections displayed across various wings, the church, cloisters and courtyards. A visit here is a wonderful introduction to the history of tiles in Portugal. To uncover the secrets of this centuries-old tradition, we’ll make our way up the hill to a little atelier near the medieval castle of Saint George. At this studio, our local craftswoman produces replicas of tilework for museums, palaces and private collectors. The tiles are all hand-modelled, painted and glazed on-site. Inspiration and hands-on encouragement abound to get your creative juices flowing as you paint your own unique tile.

 Art is not a handicraft, it is the transmission of feeling the artist has experienced

– Leo Tolstoy – Russian writer (1828 – 1910) –

fields.intro: There is no better way to understand the psyche of the people of Lisbon than to enjoy a few days celebrating the feast of their patron saint with them.
fields.intro_mobile: There is no better way to understand the psyche of the people of Lisbon than to enjoy a few days celebrating the feast of their patron saint with them.

flexible.wysiwyg:
The festival of Saint Anthony on 12th and 13th June is the party of the year in Lisbon. Saint Anthony, is the patron saint of Portugal and is much loved not only by his fellow countrymen but also across the world, where he’s known as Saint Anthony of Padua, the Italian city where he died. He was born Fernando Martins de Bulhões in what is now Saint Anthony’s church in Lisbon in 1195 and died on 13th June 1231, which is why his feast is celebrated on this day. The party-like celebrations take place on the 12th June, including the collective Saint Anthony wedding, plus the Marchas Populares, a carnival-style parade.

The historic quarters of city are decorated with colourful paper bunting and the streets fill with people and smoke billowing up from the sardines seemingly being grilled on every street corner! Eating and drinking is very much part of this festival.

Although the religious celebrations take place on 13th June, Lisbon has a party-like buzz for almost the whole of the month. A walk around the old parts of the city at this time of year is fascinating, even more so in the company of our local resident who will explain the myriad of customs from how to grill sardines, to learning about the traditional Fado singing, and the stalls selling pots of bush basil topped with paper flowers. Poems expressing affection are attached to toothpicks and poke out like small flags in the basil. People buy them to give to their loved ones; it’s yet another tradition associated with the Feast of St Anthony. If there’s a month to enjoy this fascinating city, June is the winner!

The value of things is not the time they last, but the intensity with which they occur. That is why there are unforgettable moments and unique people!

– Fernando Pessoa. Portuguese writer (1888 – 1935) –

flexible.wysiwyg: If you love fashion and people, if you seek out originality and quality then this experience is for you. Discover Lisbon’s fashion scene in the company of a local fashion designer and get to feel how this traditional yet vibrant and cosmopolitan city has its own particular approach to this booming industry.

Visit designers’ ateliers, concept stores, handmade eyewear shops and contemporary jewellery galleries as well as traditional craftsmen. You will get to learn about the Portuguese fashion landscape and get a feel for the everyday life of creative Lisboetas. This is an exclusive opportunity to meet designers in person, in their own studios and ateliers – top Portuguese designers whose work is shown on runways and in fashion magazines around the world.

Everyday is a fashion show and the world is the runway

fields.intro: The forested hills of Sintra provide a spectacular backdrop to fairytale palaces, hilltop castles and exotic gardens. The enchanting UNESCO World Heritage landscape of Sintra is simply unmissable.
fields.intro_mobile: The forested hills of Sintra provide a spectacular backdrop to fairytale palaces, hilltop castles and exotic gardens. The enchanting UNESCO World Heritage landscape of Sintra is simply unmissable.

flexible.wysiwyg:
Just a stone’s throw away from Lisbon, lies the picturesque town of Sintra. Portuguese royalty chose the idyllic hills of Sintra to escape the summer heat of Lisbon creating in the process a spell-binding enclave. It much deserves its UNESCO World Heritage title.

Beautiful palaces, such as Palacio da Pena, Palacio Nacional or Quinta Regaleira, in myriad of styles of architecture are all definitely worth visiting if you have the time.  We can help you beat the queues and the crowds and organise a private, out-of-hours tour of whichever most takes your fancy.

On top of that we can organise a visit of their gardens with the landscape architect and garden historian who was responsible for returning one particular set of gardens to its former glory.  This is a must for anyone who fancies themselves blessed with green fingers.

Look deep into nature and then you will understand everything better

Albert Einstein – German physicist (1879 – 1955)

fields.intro: Fatima has been welcoming millions of pilgrims and the curious alike for over a century. It is one of the most important pilgrimage destinations in Europe and the sight of the devout approaching the shrine on their knees is something to behold as is the sheer size of the sanctuary itself.
fields.intro_mobile: Fatima has been welcoming millions of pilgrims and the curious alike for over a century. It is one of the most important pilgrimage destinations in Europe and the sight of the devout approaching the shrine on their knees is something to behold as is the sheer size of the sanctuary itself.

flexible.wysiwyg: Portugal has long been one of the most important cradles of Christianity in Europe, along with Spain, France and Italy. Its capital Lisbon has been the birthplace, not only of sailors, but of some of the best-known saints in the world, such as Saint Anthony. We can visit his birthplace and even access his only reliquary in Lisbon.

Under two hours away from the Portuguese capital lies Fatima. It is one of the most important shrines to the Virgin Mary in the world and receives millions of faithful every year to celebrate the anniversary of the apparitions of the Virgin to three shepherd children from the neighboring village of Aljustrel. Two of the children – Francisco and Jacinta Marto, were eventually canonized by Pope Francis on 13 May, 2017, coinciding with the centenary of the apparitions. See the original houses where the protagonists of this fascinating story were born and lived and meet the handful of relatives that are still alive. The experience would not be complete without visiting some of the monuments near the sanctuary and declared UNESCO World Heritage Sites, such as the Batalha Monastery or the Convent of Christ in Tomar, founded by the Knights Templar in the 12th century and where the knights of the Order of Christ lived after the extinction of the Order of the Temple. Visit these truly fascinating corners full of history, some with restricted access, with our local guides.

All children trust in the heart of their mother and have in her a place of special affection

– Sister Lucia dos Santos. Nun and seer of Fatima. (1907 – 2005) –

fields.intro: A path less traveled for sure, the Portuguese Coastal Camino is one of the most scenic pilgrimage routes to Santiago.
fields.intro_mobile: A path less traveled for sure, the Portuguese Coastal Camino is one of the most scenic pilgrimage routes to Santiago.

flexible.wysiwyg: From Mary to St. James, from Fatima to Santiago de Compostela… According to Christian tradition, the Virgin Mary appeared to Saint James while he was spreading the gospel in the “faraway lands of Hispania”. Join us and we will take you on a journey that will unite these two great devotions for pilgrims, the Marian shrine of Fatima and hiking the most scenic part of the “Camino de Santiago” along the Portuguese coastline.

Lisbon, the charismatic and cosmopolitan capital of Portugal is the first stop on a pilgrimage full of history and local devotion as we move north to the little town of Fatima, where over 100 years ago Our Lady of the Rosary appeared to three ordinary local children.  At a complete change of pace, we will head north and embark on an “off-the-beaten-path” walking pilgrimage following in the footsteps of the millions of travelers, from across the world, who have gone before us. Feel the ocean breeze on your skin while discussing the catch of the day with local fishermen or simply enjoy a stroll around the old city of Santiago de Compostela and join the pilgrims’ mass at its impressive Romanesque 9th century cathedral. The pilgrims’ blessing at the end with the use of “el botafumeiro”, the world’s biggest thurible (incense burner), is the grand finale to this unique religious experience.

One day you will wake up and there won’t be any more time to do the things you’ve always wanted to do. Do it now!

– Paulo Coelho. Brazilian novelist (born 1947) –

fields.intro: Discover the beautiful Douro Valley, declared World Heritatge by UNESCO, where the Douro river flows through the vineyards creating some of the best wines in Portugal

flexible.wysiwyg: The Douro Valley is famous for its wine production, but it is also a region of outstanding natural beauty and for many the best way to enjoy the scenery is from the water. The Douro is the 3rd longest river in the Iberian Peninsula and from its source in northern Spain, vineyards and wineries populate its riverbanks. For one hundred and twelve kilometers the river forms part of the border between Spain and Portugal and the canyon type terrain has created a unique fjord-like landscape that makes exploring the area by boat is simply a not-to-be-missed experience.

We have access to a top of the range yacht and amongst the crew we will have one of the area’s best chefs to prepare a feast fit for such a spectacular backdrop; we will be accompanied by a local expert in the region of the Douro who will explain everything from the history behind port wine, the wine production in general to stunning terraced landscape.  As we set foot on the ground again, our final destination will be a private visit to a local vineyard with the opportunity to learn a bit more and sample some of the world-class wines they produce.

The sublime Douro. The prodigy of a landscape that ceases to be by the force of being uncurbed. It is not a panorama that the eyes contemplate: it is an excess of nature.

– Miguel Torga –

fields.intro: Porto is the second-largest city in Portugal, and one of the oldest in Europe. The old city centre is so captivating and full of charm that it comes as no surprise that it's a UNESCO World Heritage Site. But did you also know about its links with Harry Potter?

flexible.wysiwyg:
Porto is a city best seen on foot. Although like Lisbon, any walking entails steep hills and cobble stones!

This walking tour examines the oft disputed links between Harry Potter and the inspiration that it may have provided to his creator, JK Rowling, when she lived here. See the café where she used to stop for a coffee and where she apparently started working on her first Harry Potter book. Does that staircase seem familiar? Well, no wonder, rumor has it, that there is a particular bookshop whose staircase is said to be the inspiration behind the library at Hogwarts. As you walk round the streets of Porto in the company of a Harry Potter die-hard fan you’ll find other references for sure! Look out for the university students in their black capes and those brooms in that old-school brush shop look a lot like a Nimbus 2000!

I think I’ll just go down and have some pudding and wait for it all to turn up — it always does in the end

― Luna Lovegood. Misty-eyed WIzard ―

fields.intro: The Douro region offers breath-taking landscapes all year round, but at harvest time, when the grapes are ready to be picked, the colors are just dazzling. Explore the wine-making tradition here with Spain Collection.
fields.intro_mobile: The Douro region offers breath-taking landscapes all year round, but at harvest time, when the grapes are ready to be picked, the colors are just dazzling. Explore the wine-making tradition here with Spain Collection.

flexible.wysiwyg:
For many wine lovers, seeing the grape harvest process first-hand and tasting the end product just isn’t enough. And we completely agree with that sentiment! Enjoy the unique opportunity to experience a day in the life of a wine-maker and take part in the harvest. There is nothing like seeing first-hand the relationship between the terroir and the passion that makes wine a reality.

The Douro is one of the only wine regions in the world which still continues with tradition of grape treading.  So you have to get both your hands and your feet dirty, and make your own mark on this year’s vintage!

The grape harvest usually happens towards the end of September, although the exact timing depends on the weather during the growing season and the forecast for September rains. Too much rain when the grapes are ripe will spoil them so timing is crucial. Are you ready to roll up your sleeves and trouser legs?

As the soil, however rich, cannot bear fruit if it is not cultivated, the mind without cultivation cannot produce either

– Seneca –

fields.intro: Explore the stunning landscape of the Ria Formosa Natural with a local fisherman and his Portuguese Water Dog. We learn how to pick clams and sample the exquisite Algarve oysters - they don’t get fresher than this!
fields.intro_mobile: Explore the stunning landscape of the Ria Formosa Natural with a local fisherman and his Portuguese Water Dog. We learn how to pick clams and sample the exquisite Algarve oysters - they don’t get fresher than this!

flexible.wysiwyg: With over 1,000 miles of coastline, it’s no wonder that fishing is so strongly linked to many Portuguese traditions. Join us in this unique opportunity to spend the day with a local fisherman on his daily clam picking tasks. The activity takes place in the heart of the natural park of Ria Formosa, a protected lagoon and home to many species of fauna and flora. Our transport will be a traditional wooden boat and our guide will be a local experienced skipper/fisherman, in the company of his Portuguese Water Dog. We will learn the old ways of clam and razor clam picking and make a stop at an oyster farm to taste the oysters directly from the producer perfectly paired with a glass of VINHO VERDE.

The sea, the great unifier, is man’s only hope. Now, as never before, the old phrase has a literal meaning: we are all in the same boat

– Jacques Yves Cousteau –

fields.intro: The waterways and lagoons of the Ria Formosa Natural Park are a delight in themselves but let’s also discover the underwater world of the Algarve, and the area’s fascinating seahorse population.
fields.intro_mobile: The waterways and lagoons of the Ria Formosa Natural Park are a delight in themselves but let’s also discover the underwater world of the Algarve, and the area’s fascinating seahorse population.

flexible.wysiwyg: When it comes to learn about seahorses and other amazing local marine fauna, the expression “dive-in” is very appropriate. Near Faro, the Ria Formosa Natural Park is home to one of the largest seahorse communities in the world. The resident species here are the long-snouted seahorse and the short-snouted seahorse, but you will also get see octopus, cuttlefish and sea snails.

Our boat skipper will be your guide, sharing his passion and knowledge whilst showing you the natural beauty of this area of the Algarve as well as help you to identify the different seahorses. This experience is done within the Ria Formosa lagoon system and the dive is performed with just a diving mask and snorkel (all equipment provided). The depth of the water is only 1.50m-1.80m yet being able to swim is necessary.

We are tied to the ocean. And when we go back to the sea, whether it is to sail or to watch – we are going back from whence we came

– John F. Kennedy –

fields.intro: Age-old traditions, a fascinating culture, and a stunning natural landscape… head inland and off-the-beaten track to discover another side to the Algarve, a world away from the beaches and their sun-worshippers.
fields.intro_mobile: Age-old traditions, a fascinating culture, and a stunning natural landscape… head inland and off-the-beaten track to discover another side to the Algarve, a world away from the beaches and their sun-worshippers.

flexible.wysiwyg:
If you head inland from the coast, pretty much from anywhere in the Algarve you will find a different world. In some cases, it’s like stepping back in time. The hills of the region are full of surprises if you know where to look. To make sure you see everything you will head out on this activity by jeep and your driver will be your guide.
Along the way you will see olive trees, carob trees, orange trees, and the arbutus tree which is the source of the berry-like fruits which make the local firewater – ‘medronho’.

Olives are a way of life here in the Algarve. The region’s climate and soil composition make it the perfect place for olive farming. Many of the trees you’ll see will be centuries old. And whilst carobs, or ‘Alfaroba’, are not the most attractive fruits of the Algarve, they are worth their weight in gold – literally! Carob pods, which hang from magnificent evergreen trees, turn from green to brown and are ready to harvest in August. Regardless of the size of the pod, each seed inside weighs exactly the same. For this reason, in times gone by, carob seeds were used to weigh diamonds, silver and gold.

Probably the most striking thing you will see on this fascinating tour are the cork trees – easy to spot by their stripped bark. Each cork oak tree can survive for up to 200 years and once a tree reaches 25 years of age, it can be stripped of its cork once every 9 to 12 years without causing any permanent damage to the tree. It’s the only tree that’s able to regenerate its bark. Portugal is the world’s main exporter of cork and it’s the cork produced right here in the Algarve that’s considered to be the best. Cork has many uses, from insulation material for ships, to table mats, protective packaging and, of course, bottle stoppers. Nowadays cork is incorporated into fashion items such as handbags, mobile phone cases, umbrellas and even articles of clothing.

It seems to me that the natural world is the greatest source of excitement; the greatest source of visual beauty; the greatest source of intellectual interest. It is the greatest source of so much in life that makes life worth living

– David Attenborough –

2566.title: Carnival Fever on the Canary Islands

experiences.name: Culture
experiences.description: Spain and Portugal combined have more UNESCO World Heritage Sites than any other place in the world.

destinations.description: Mallorca, Tenerife, Ibiza, Lanzarote, Menorca … it’s impossible to sum up the islands in a couple of sentences when they are all so unique in their own right...

fields.intro: Celia Cruz used to say that life is a carnival, and she should know as someone who taught the world to dance. And they know a lot about carnival in the Canary Islands, so, following that analogy, maybe we can learn something about life and happiness here.
fields.intro_mobile: Celia Cruz used to say that life is a carnival, and she should know as someone who taught the world to dance. And they know a lot about carnival in the Canary Islands, so, following that analogy, maybe we can learn something about life and happiness here.

flexible.wysiwyg:
There will be no carnivals in Tenerife or Gran Canaria in 2021. The Canaries, like the rest of the world, are adapting to regulations currently in place to combat the COVID-19 pandemic, but they know that there will be other carnivals to celebrate and that the important thing is to keep moving. And when the time comes and the carnivals are back, Spain Collection will be there to give you a ‘behind the scenes’ experience at one of the best parties in Europe.

We can do this activity in the 3 – 4 weeks prior to the Carnival Queen Gala Event which takes place – depending on when Easter falls – in either February or March. It is one of the most famous carnivals in the world, comparable only to Rio de Janeiro or Venice.

During our visit to the historic colonial city of Santa Cruz, in Tenerife, we will take you to the workshop of one of the greatest designers on the islands. See where this winner of several Carnivals creates his ‘fantasies’ (as these exquisitely baroque carnival designs are called) and experience the pre-competition nerves. The Carnival Queen Gala is a highly competitive event, the designers work all year round on their creations and this is the moment of truth. The visit wraps up with a glass of cava at the workshop, in a sea of sequins!

 

And if you are really in the mood for a party, you can also join in with the carnival celebrations – we’ll find you a costume and you can join in with the fun like a local. You can even attend the gala event itself and have yourself a ball amongst all the glitter and feathers.

 

‘Ay, no need to cry (no need to cry)

Life is a carnival

What is more beautiful than to live singing’

– Celia Cruz, Singer & actress (1925 – 2003)

2792.title: Jai-Alai, The Most Universal Basque Sport

experiences.name: Sports
experiences.description: Do you enjoy sports from an armchair or do you prefer to be out in the thick of it?

destinations.name: Euskadi & Northern Spain
destinations.description: Whether you’re looking for the most amazing food, breath-taking scenery or ground-breaking architecture, northern Spain shatters any stereotype of our country.

fields.intro: There are moments in history when nations come together and unite, when their paths cross and they are connected forever. Sports - just like traveling - have this distinguishing feature of  bringing people together.

flexible.wysiwyg: The Basque sport of ‘cesta-punta’, more commonly known as ‘Jai-Alai’ in the United States, spread across the world at the beginning of the 20th century: Cuba, Argentina, the United States, Australia… No country could resist this incredible spectacle which holds the Guinness World Record for fastest projectile speed in any moving ball game at almost 190mph.

This sport has its origins in the Basque Country: here every town and every city, has its own pelota court: an open-air public space where the locals usually play handball (the most popular version, which is played with the naked hand). And of course, all over the Basque Country we find covered courts for the practice of cesta-punta, venues where adrenaline pumps, and where the locals make bets on their players and vent their excitement with every move.

In cities like Bilbao, San Sebastián or Logroño there are huge courts, but let’s not forget important ‘temples’ such as Gernika Jai-Alai or Markina’s court, also known as ‘the university of the ball’.Spain Collection wants you to get to grips with this sport so we’ll head down onto a court and meet some players to learn the rules and their rituals.  See the well-worn ’baskets’ and the players’ hands calloused by the game. Hold the equipment and understand the dynamics of the basket-tip. And of course, we will be able to try our hand at a game with the help of the players.
 

It’s the thrill, the emotion, the excitement. Everything happens so fast your eyes can barely see it. Impossible as it seems, the player has caught the ball with his basket and there it goes again
– Anonymous supporter –
